(7) Marvin Lord7 (Amelia Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 29 JAN 1784 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 7 FEB 1784 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
(7) Mary Lord7 (Amelia Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1786 , d. 1827 Carlisle, Schoharie Co., New York.
m. 1803 , Montgomery Co., New York, John Boughten Roscoe, b. 3 JAN 1777 New Canaan, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. 9 NOV 1865 Carlisle, Schoharie Co., New York.
Spouse NotesJOHN B. Roscoe came from Essex Co., New York, to Carlisle, and settled with the Lord family in 1805, and was the first physician in Carlisle. Hen continued his practice for nearly 60 years. He purchased 10 acres of land in 1810 and settled there and had a family of 2 sons and 3 daughters.
2 children: Boughton, Emily Eliza.
(8) Boughton Roscoe8 (Mary Lord7, Amelia Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1805 , d. 1892 King, San Bernardino Co., California.

NotesBERTHA Dean of Auburn New York, joined the Wolcott Society in 1915. She attended the Syracuse reunion with a cousin. She rejoined in 1976 as member #1043, residing at Auburn, New York.

(10) Clarence Field10 (Sarah Elizabeth Lord9, Mary Elizabeth Hawes8, Ursula Lord7, Amelia Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1887 , d. .
(8) Mary E. Hawes8 (Ursula Lord7, Amelia Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , Schoharie Co., New York, d. .

(7) Betsey Lord7 (Amelia Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 11 AUG 1794 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
(7) Tryphena Lord7 (Amelia Wolcott6, Roger Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 MAR 1803 Lyme, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. .
(6) Martha Wolcott6 (Roger Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 23 APR 1753 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 MAY 1753 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Roger Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 14 SEP 1704 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 10 OCT 1759 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived in South Windsor, his property adjoining that of his uncle, Henry. He was a Representative for Windsor at the General Assembly, a Major in the Connecticut militia, a member of the Council, and Judge of the Hartford County Court and the Superior Court of Connecticut. Roger was one of those appointed to revise the laws of the Connecticut Colony, and was one of three commissioners appointed by the Colony of Connecticut to meet at Albany in 1745 with representatives of other colonies, to discuss a plan for union. He was one of the subscribers to the Susquehanna Land Company in 1753.
m. 19 JUN 1759 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Eunice Colton, b. 22 FEB 1706 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 29 MAR 1778 Bolton, Worcester Co., Massachusetts.
(5) Elizabeth Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 10 APR 1706 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 JUL 1775 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesELIZABETH received a pension from the British government for her husband's military service. It was paid in merchandise, which she sold from her home at Wintonbury, now Bloomfield. Her account books and scales used in this mercantile business for 1739 to 1741 were in the possession of her great-grandson. Oliver Dwight Filley of Bloomfield.
m. 27 AUG 1727 Roger Newberry, b. 4 JUN 1706 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 6 MAY 1741 ,, Cuba.
Spouse NotesROGER graduated from Yale College in 1726. He commanded a company of soldiers sent to fight in the West Indies, and died at sea while returning from this expedition. Roger and his wife, Elizabeth were second cousins.
7 children: Elizabeth, Hannah, Abigail, Roger, Sarah, Benjamin, Thomas.
(6) Elizabeth Newberry6 (Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 JUN 1728 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 JUN 1749 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 16 FEB 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Daniel Bissell, b. 2 FEB 1724 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. BEF 1824 Randolph, Orange Co., Vermont.
Spouse NotesDANIEL was a descendant of Gov. William Bradford, who came to America on the Mayflower.
2 children: Elizabeth, Newberry.
(7) Elizabeth Bissell7 (Elizabeth Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 FEB 1747 Windsor Locks, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 JUL 1833 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 10 NOV 1769 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Jabez Haskell, b. 15 NOV 1746 Rochester, Plymouth Co., Massachusetts, d. 4 SEP 1816 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
3 children: Lucinda, Wealthy, Harris.

m. 18 JAN 1796 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Harper Partridge, b. 11 JUN 1769 , d. .
8 children: Jasper, Harriet, Lucinda, Orpha, Harper, Almira, Harris Sidney, Caroline.

(9) Samuel Strong Hayden9 (Wealthy Haskell8, Elizabeth Bissell7, Elizabeth Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 OCT 1813 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 APR 1863 Irish Bend, St. Mary Parish, Louisiana.
NotesSAMUEL joined the militia at age 18, rose to the rank of Major of the 1st Regiment at age 49. He secured the raising of a company from Windsor, Company C, 25th Regual Connecticut Volunteers, at which he was in command when repelling a rebel charge with the words on his lips "Dont' run borys" when he was killed.

(6) Abigail Newberry6 (Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 DEC 1733 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. 18 JAN 1770 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, William Russell, b. 23 JUL 1725 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 19 APR 1775 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Roger Newberry6 (Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 JUN 1735 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 FEB 1814 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived on the Newberry homestead in Windsor until his death. He was a lawyer and a successful merchant. He held commissions as Lieutenant and as Captain under the English Crown, but at the commencement of the American Revolution he promptly engaged himself in the service of the Colonies. He was commissioned Major General in the Connecticut State militia. Roger served four years as a member of the Governor's Council. He was a Judge of Probate, and Judge of the County Court. He was a member of the upper house of the Connecticut Legislature from 1799 to 1809, and received an honorary degree from Yale College. Tradition says that he bore a striking resemblance to his maternal grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott. Roger and his wife, Eunice, were 2nd cousins.
m. 9 JAN 1759 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Hannah Allyn, b. ABT 1740 , d. 23 FEB 1760 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Roger Newberry6 (Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 JUN 1735 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 FEB 1814 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER lived on the Newberry homestead in Windsor until his death. He was a lawyer and a successful merchant. He held commissions as Lieutenant and as Captain under the English Crown, but at the commencement of the American Revolution he promptly engaged himself in the service of the Colonies. He was commissioned Major General in the Connecticut State militia. Roger served four years as a member of the Governor's Council. He was a Judge of Probate, and Judge of the County Court. He was a member of the upper house of the Connecticut Legislature from 1799 to 1809, and received an honorary degree from Yale College. Tradition says that he bore a striking resemblance to his maternal grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott. Roger and his wife, Eunice, were 2nd cousins.

(9) Henry Strong Newberry9 (Henry Newberry8, Henry Newberry7, Roger Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 NOV 1850 , d. .

1 children: Elizabeth.
(10) Elizabeth Newberry10 (Henry Strong Newberry9, Henry Newberry8, Henry Newberry7, Roger Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 3 OCT 1881 , d. .
(8) John Strong Newberry8 (Henry Newberry7, Roger Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 DEC 1822 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesJOHN graduated from Western Reserve College in 1846 and received his M.D. from the Cleveland Medical College in 1848. He was in Europe in 1849/1850 and commenced the practice of medicine in 1851. In May 1855 he was appointed by the U.S. War Department as Surgeon and Geologist of Williamson's Expedition for the exploration of Northern California and Oregon, which took the next six years. He was then appointed to the Ives Expedition to Southern California and New Mexico. In 1861 he was appointed Secretary of the Western Department, U.S. Sanitary Commission. John was appointed Professor of Geology and Paleontology in the School of Mines, Columbia College, New York City. In 1860 he was appointed Chief of the Ohio State Geological Survey; was President of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1867-1889. He was President of the Torrey Botanical Club, 1886-1889; was an original incorporator of the National Academy of Sciences, and was President of the American Association for the Advacement of Science.
m. 12 OCT 1848 Sarah Brownell Gaylord, b. 16 DEC 1823 Madison, Madison Co., New York, d. .
7 children: Cleveland Gaylord, Arthur St. John, Spencer Baird, Elizabeth Strong, Wolcott Ely, Robert Thorne, William Belknap.
(9) Cleveland Gaylord Newberry9 (John Strong Newberry8, Henry Newberry7, Roger Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 JAN 1851 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 10 FEB 1882 Corralitos,, Mexico.
NotesCleveland received his M.D. from Cleveland Medical College in 1875.
m. FEB 1876 Minnie Keith, b. , d. .
1 children: Keith Cleveland.

NotesArthur graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1872; received a B.A. from Harvard College in 1976 and was admitted to the Ohio bar in 1878.
m. 11 NOV 1880 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, Emma Paige Eelis, b. 8 APR 1857 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
3 children: Winifred Eelis, John Strong, Mary Witt.
(10) Winifred Eelis Newberry10 (Arthur St. John Newberry9, John Strong Newberry8, Henry Newberry7, Roger Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 SEP 1881 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
(10) John Strong Newberry10 (Arthur St. John Newberry9, John Strong Newberry8, Henry Newberry7, Roger Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 8 APR 1883 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
(10) Mary Witt Newberry10 (Arthur St. John Newberry9, John Strong Newberry8, Henry Newberry7, Roger Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 JUN 1885 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
(9) Spencer Baird Newberry9 (John Strong Newberry8, Henry Newberry7, Roger Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 11 MAY 1857 , d. .
NotesSpencer received a M.E. from the School of Mines, Columbia College, New York City in 1878 and a Ph.D. in 1879. He studied at the University of Berlin, 1879-1880; Paris, 1880-1881; was assistant in chemistry, Cornell University, 1 November 1881 and Professor of chemistry and mineral in 1882. He was U.S. Commissioner to the Paris Exposition in 1889. His wifes father, was the President of Cornell University and the U.S. Minister to Germany. Source #70, Vol. II, page 532-533.

(9) Asahel E. Olcott9 (Frances Olcott8, Sarah Mather7, Sarah Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 4 NOV 1831 Windsor Locks, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 4 APR 1886 .
(9) William Henry Olcott9 (Frances Olcott8, Sarah Mather7, Sarah Newberry6, Elizabeth Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 MAR 1834 , d. 22 MAY 1888 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
NotesWilliam graduated from Yale in 1859, studied medicine and surgery in Northampton and Pittsfield, Massachusetts, and with Dr. Valentine Mott, New York city. He settled in Brooklyn; was assistant surgeon for the 173rd New York Regiment last in the Civil War and had charge of hospitals at Baton Rouge, Louisiana. He served through the war and was breveted Lt. Col. for meritorious service.

(5) Alexander Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 JAN 1708 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 OCT 1711 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER was killed by a cart wheel.
(5) Samuel Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 JAN 1710 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 27 DEC 1717 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Alexander Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.
m. 4 DEC 1732 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Lydia Roswell Atwater, b. 18 OCT 1715 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 28 JAN 1776 Cromwell, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesLYDIA divorced her husband, Alexander Wolcott, at his request. Both remarried.
3 children: Jeremiah, Alexander, Lydia.
(6) Jeremiah Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 3 NOV 1733 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 12 MAY 1792 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesJEREMIAH was a physician at Branford, Connecticut. He may have been the Jeremiah Woolcott who served during the Revolutionary War. In 1773 Sarah Wolcott of Branford obtained a divorce from him

4 children: William R, Frederick Ferdinand, Henry Augustus, George Edward.
(9) William R Street9 (Martha Davenport Wolcott Reynolds8, Martha Davenport Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 12 JUL 1828 , d. .
m. Elizabeth T. Upson, b. , d. .
(9) Frederick Ferdinand Street9 (Martha Davenport Wolcott Reynolds8, Martha Davenport Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 26 JAN 1830 Cheshire, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1921 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesFREDERICK F. Street of Hartford was a member of the Wolcott Society 1909-16. He and his wife entertained in their home at Hartford those attending the 1913 reunion at Hartford. In 1919 he reported that the apple trees planted by Henry Wolcott were still alive, but "only here and there a limb showing foliage and occasionally some fruit." He said that the Wolcott homestead was then owned by the Loomis School. In 1920 he made a donation of $100 to the fund to restore the Old State House at Hartford in the name of the Henry Wolcott family.

NotesWOLCOTT travelled extensively up and down the East coast of the United States. He kept a journal of his travels from 1841 to 1844 which was published in a 306 page volume.

(10) Pauline M. Harrison10 (Wolcott Reynolds Harrison9, Sarah Goodsell Reynolds8, Martha Davenport Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1 JAN 1849 North Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. .

m. Margaret Belden, b. , d. .
1 children: Lovell "Birge".
(10) Lovell "Birge" Harrison10 (Appollos Wolcott Harrison9, Sarah Goodsell Reynolds8, Martha Davenport Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 OCT 1854 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. .
NotesBIRGE was a artist. His line descend from Thomas Harrison, who was Major General to Oliver Cromwell, signed the death warrant of King Charles I of England, and conducted him to the scaffold; and whose son, Thomas, emigrated from England in 1640 and settle at Branford, Connecticut.

Birge was educated at the private academies of Philadelphia; went to Paris in 1875 and studied painting in the Ecole des beaus arts, under Alexandre Cabanel. He made trip around the world, painting in Australia, the South Seas, California and among the American Indians, 1889-1893. H was elected a member of the Society of American Artist, and received a silver medal at the Exposition Universal in 1889 and a unique medal from the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893.
(8) Thomas Goodsell Reynolds8 (Martha Davenport Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 16 MAR 1798 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 26 SEP 1826 .

NotesWILLIAM was a merchant and broker at New Haven.
m. New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Jane Lynde, b. , d. .
(8) Beverly Reynolds8 (Martha Davenport Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 NOV 1806 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 5 NOV 1807 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
(7) Thomas Goodsell Wolcott7 (Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 AUG 1764 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 22 JAN 1847 New York City, New York.
NotesTHOMAS was expelled from Yale College in his Junior year for participating in a serious disorder and was not admitted to a degree until a year after his class had graduated. He received a BA from Yale College in 1783. He was a member of "Brothers in Unity", a Yale fraternity which maintained a library and reading room at Yale. . In 1790 he was at North Haven, Connecticut, with a family of 1 male over 16 and 3 females. He was teaching school at North Branford in 1792. In 1840 he was at New York City. He died in the Alms House at New York City.
m. 27 MAY 1789 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Lucy Hoffman, b. 5 FEB 1769 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1830 .
6 children: Sarah Goodsell, Nancy Green, Eliza, Alexander, Martha Davenport, Lucretia.
(8) Sarah Goodsell Wolcott8 (Thomas Goodsell Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 19 MAR 1790 North Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1822 Branford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesSARAH wrote poetry and played the guitar. Her sister, Eliza, wrote "The Two Sisters, Poems and Memories", published by Baldway & Stradway, New Haven, 1830, containing many of Sarah's poems. She and her husband moved to Southwick, Massachusetts after their marriage. After his death she returned to her parents' home with her son and had a school.

NotesELIZA and her sister, Sarah, wrote and published "The Two Sisters' Poems and Memoirs", published in 1830. Most of the poems were written by Sarah, and the memoirs by Eliza.

(10) Harrison10 (John Davenport Harrison9, Jeremiah W. Harrison8, Sarah Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .
(8) James Harrison8 (Sarah Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 DEC 1786 , d. 18 FEB 1861 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
m. Charlotte Lynde, b. 1813 ,, Connecticut, d. .
Spouse NotesCHARLOTTE lived with her son Henry and daughter Florence at New Haven, Connecticut, in 1880.
6 children: Hart Lynde "Lynde", Janet Shepherd, Henry N., Ella Louisa, Eleanore Florence, Arthur W..
(9) Hart Lynde "Lynde" Harrison9 (James Harrison8, Sarah Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 DEC 1837 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesLYNDE graduated from Yale Law School in 1860. He was a lawyer in New Haven, Connecticut starting in 1863. He was clerk of the Connecticut House of Representative and Senate in 1862, 1863 and 1864 and was elected as a Republican to the Connecticut state senate in 1865 and 1866. He served as a Lieutenant in the Quartermaster Corps, 27th Connecticut Regt., during the Civil War. From 1874 until 1877 he was the representative from Guilford and was Speaker of the lower house in 1877. He was a judge of the city court and then Judge of the New Haven County Court of Common Pleas. He delivered an oration at the 1889 Gettysburg Battlefield reunion.
m. 2 MAY 1867 ,, Connecticut, Sarah Plant, b. Of Branford,, Connecticut, d. MAR 1879 Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
2 children: William Lynde "Willie", Paul.
(10) William Lynde "Willie" Harrison10 (Hart Lynde "Lynde" Harrison9, James Harrison8, Sarah Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1868 ,, Connecticut, d. .
(10) Paul Harrison10 (Hart Lynde "Lynde" Harrison9, James Harrison8, Sarah Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1871 ,, Connecticut, d. .
(9) Hart Lynde "Lynde" Harrison9 (James Harrison8, Sarah Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 DEC 1837 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesLYNDE graduated from Yale Law School in 1860. He was a lawyer in New Haven, Connecticut starting in 1863. He was clerk of the Connecticut House of Representative and Senate in 1862, 1863 and 1864 and was elected as a Republican to the Connecticut state senate in 1865 and 1866. He served as a Lieutenant in the Quartermaster Corps, 27th Connecticut Regt., during the Civil War. From 1874 until 1877 he was the representative from Guilford and was Speaker of the lower house in 1877. He was a judge of the city court and then Judge of the New Haven County Court of Common Pleas. He delivered an oration at the 1889 Gettysburg Battlefield reunion.
m. 30 SEP 1886 Harriet S. White, b. Of Waterbury,, Connecticut, d. .
(9) Janet Shepherd Harrison9 (James Harrison8, Sarah Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 MAR 1840 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesJANET studied art with Louis Bail in New Haven and with her husband-to-be in Rome, Paris and Venice. She was elected an associate of the National Academy of Design in 1875 and in 1901 was one of three women on the list of associated national academicians. She became well known as a painter of portraits and regular exhibitor at the academy. "Baby Belle"; "Little Runaway"; "Bouguet for Mamma" are named as especially noteworthy.
m. 1865 Henry Augustus Loop, b. Of New York City, New York, d. .
(9) Henry N. Harrison9 (James Harrison8, Sarah Wolcott7, Jeremiah Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1848 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1880 .
NotesHENRY N. Harrison was a bookeeper at New Haven, Connecticut, in 1880.
m. Louisa , b. 1850 ,, Connecticut, d. .

NotesFLORENCE is listed as a daughter, age 24, living with Charlotte Harrison in 1880.

NotesALEXANDER was killed in the French-Indian War while serving under his grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott.
(6) Lydia Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 4 NOV 1737 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 6 MAY 1820 Coventry, Tolland Co., Connecticut.

NotesSamuel graduated from Yale University in 1783, and was President of the University of Vermont.

NotesWILLIAM was a Deacon in his church.

(8) Samuel Austin8 (William Austin7, Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. FEB 1794 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. SEP 1795 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
(8) Samuel Austin8 (William Austin7, Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .
(8) Nathan Austin8 (William Austin7, Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. JUL 1797 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. SEP 1798 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
(8) Joseph Austin8 (William Austin7, Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1799 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. JAN 1828 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.

(7) Lydia Austin7 (Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 DEC 1764 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 28 APR 1829 .
NotesLYDIA made a statement at Rockville on 13 Aug, 1842, stating she was born New Haven 9 Dec. 1764, daughter of Samuel Austin and of a daughter of Dr. Alexander Wolcott, that she was under the ministry of Dr. Jonathan Edwards until age 26 at the time of her marriage to Rev. David Hale of Lisbon. In 1804 due to her husband's health he was dismissed and they moved to Coventry. He died in 1822,
m. David Hale, b. 15 DEC 1761 Coventry, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. FEB 1822 ,, Connecticut.
2 children: Laura, David.

NotesDAVID was an author.

Spouse NotesLAURA and her husband were cousins.
2 children: Richard, David Austin.
(9) Richard Hale9 (David Hale8, Lydia Austin7, Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1820 , d. .

(10) William Nelson Hale10 (David Austin Hale9, David Hale8, Lydia Austin7, Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1850 , d. 1855 .
(10) Charles Warren Hale10 (David Austin Hale9, David Hale8, Lydia Austin7, Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .
(10) Mary Agnes Hale10 (David Austin Hale9, David Hale8, Lydia Austin7, Lydia Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 29 SEP 1869 Innsbruck,, Austria, d. 14 JUN 1928 Palo Alto, Santa Clara Co., California.
(5) Alexander Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.
m. 17 MAR 1739 Mary Mansfield, b. 23 FEB 1707 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 1741 .
(5) Alexander Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 JAN 1712 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 MAR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale in 1731 and "owned the Covenant" in 1733 at the First Church of New Haven. He studied medicine with Dr. Norman Morrison at Hartford, and accompanied his father as surgeon's mate in the expedition against Louisburg during the French and Indian Wars. He settled in Windsor, where he was a practicing physician from 1740 until the 1780s. He served as Justice of the Peace and Representative of the town to the General Assembly. He succeeded his brother, Roger, as a member of the Susquehanna Land Company, of which he was a member in 1774 and 1786. He was appointed Chairman of the Windsor Committee of Safety and was head of a commission to examine applicants for becoming surgeons in the Continental Army. For his services during the war, he was awarded land at Montgomery, Franklin Co., New Hampshire. Alexander wrote poetry, some of which was published. He owned a slave named Primus who assisted him in his medical work. Primus was freed by Alexander and was known as Dr. Primus Manumit, with his own medical practice. In the 1790 census, Alexander had 1 male over 16, 3 males under 16, 2 females, and 2 free Negros living in his home at Windsor. Alexander's home, built in 1745, stood at the top of the Broad St. Green in downtown Windsor. It was moved to make room for building that is now Arthurs Drug Store. It is now at 5 Moorlands St. in Windsor. It has a huge double fireplace, a birthing room, and a 5 ft. wide vat in the attic made from one huge tree.

In the case Alexander Walcott et al. v. James Swan et al., April 1800, an appeal from the Court of Chancery, where Swan and Alexander McRae sued Walcott, Smyth and Price, saying that on 21 July 1795 they entered into contract regarding lands in Russell County whereby McRae gave Smyth, the registrar of the land office, land warrants for 300,000 acres of land in Russel County. After this Walcott gave Smyth a considerable sum of money for which Smyth gave him the warrants for which Walcott took lands in Lee County of inferior value. These lands were included in a 650,000 acre survey made for Walcott and returned to Smyth who was to issue a patent to Walcott. The suit was to enjoin Smyth from issuing the patent to Walcott and to issue 300,000 acres to Swan, or that pary of the survey orininally entered on warrents of Swan. Alexander Walcott said that in June 1795 he, David Booth and Austin Nichols of Connecticut were in Montgomery Co., Virginia, and met with Smyth who proposed to survey for them a tract on the Big Sandy River. Walcott, Booth and Nichols were to return to Connecticut and secure the mone and meet Smyth on 20 Sep. following in Richmond and Smyth was to hold the said lands for them until then. They raise sufficient money to secure 1,500,000 acres of land and returned on 20 Sept to find Smyth gone, at which time Booth and Nichols relinquished to Walcott their rights to the contract. Smyth in the meantime had issued 300,000 to Swan, but later surveyed for Swan the better land in Lee County and for Walcott 650,00 acres in Russell County. Alexander Walcott was required to assign to James Swan 3000,000 of the 650,000 acres.
1797 land grant to Alexander Wolcott of 50,000 acres in Lee Co. Virginia by Gov. James Wood
In 1807 Diggs and Keith sued Alexander Wolcott in Middlesex C. Connecticut courts for promissory notes given by him for the purchase of land in Virginia.
1822 receipt to Alexander Wolcott for redemption of land returned delinquent by the sheriff of Lee Co. Virginia.
m. 3 APR 1745 Wallingford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, Mary Richards, b. 1724 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 23 OCT 1817 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
10 children: Esther, Simon, Esther, George, George, Christopher Drake, Mary, Alexander, Guy, Elizabeth.
(6) Esther Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 SEP 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 OCT 1746 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Simon Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 AUG 1747 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 APR 1809 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesSIMON was a physician at New London, Connecticut. For several years he was Secretary of the County Medical Society. He served a surgeon of the 6th Connecticut Regiment during the Revolutionary War from 20 May 1775 until 21 December 1775 and in Col. Guy's Regiment from June to December 1776. His house and barn on "The Bank" at New London, were burned by the British during the war. In 1791 he was compensated for loss of property at New London , valued at 1,083L, by a grant of land in the Western Reserve of Ohio. In 1790 his family at New London consisted of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, and 8 females.
m. 23 JAN 1774 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Lucy Rogers, b. 1752 , d. 21 APR 1791 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
8 children: Lucretia, Alexander, Lucy, Mary, Lucy, Charlotte, Catherine, Elizabeth.
(7) Lucretia Wolcott7 (Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 JAN 1775 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 21 MAR 1823 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
m. 28 OCT 1793 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Richard Law, b. 6 MAR 1763 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 19 OCT 1845 .
Spouse NotesRICHARD was a Navy Captain during the Revolutionary War.
1 children: Mary Cecelia.
(8) Mary Cecelia Law8 (Lucretia Wolcott7, Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 FEB 1802 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 8 APR 1876 .
m. 11 OCT 1832 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Coleby Chew, b. 17 NOV 1802 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 26 NOV 1850 .
(7) Alexander Wolcott7 (Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 12 NOV 1775 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. at Sea.
NotesALEXANDER died at sea.
m. Joanna Paul, b. , d. .
1 children: Alexander Simon.
(8) Alexander Simon Wolcott8 (Alexander Wolcott7, Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1805 ,, New York, d. 10 NOV 1844 Stamford, Fairfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER was listed as an artist in New York City in 1841, and was said to have been known for his mechanical ingenuity. He was a pioneer in amateur Deguerreotype photography, working with John Johnson to create a daguerreotype camera in 1839. After the camera was patented in 1840, he traveled to Washington, D. C. and helped Stevenson open a gallery there, and in 1841 went to London to show the invention. The "New York Times" of 28 Jan 1883 stated, "Mr. A. S. Wolcott, who was for a long time in the business of daguerreotyping in this city, and afterwards opened a laboratory in London, really preceded Prof. Draper by several weeks in the application of Daguerre's discovery..., to whom may be ascribed the first image of the human face ever taken by sunlight." The question of whether Wolcott or Draper took the first photograph of a living person was hotly disputed. Alexander purchased property at Stamford, Connecticut, in 1842 and had a rolling mill there. His obituary in the Stamford Advocate reads: "Died in this village on Sunday last, of consumption, Mr. Alexander Simon Wolcott, aged 40 years." His will was probated inthe Stamford, Connecticut, court: "Wolcott, Alexander S., deceased, late of Stamford, Nov. 13 1844, his widow refused to qualify...." This record mentions Cynthia L. Wolcott, age 13, who had Humphrey Phelps of New York City appointed as her guardian. Humphrey Phelps was apparently the one who was a New York City publisher of prints and maps, 1832-53, author of "Pictorial View of the World" published New York City 1847 and "Phelps Travelers' Guides" of various cities which were published beginning in 1838.
m. 1832 Bridgeport, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, Mary Sanborn, b. 10 APR 1809 New Hampton, Belknap Co., New Hampshire, d. 20 JUL 1895 New Hampton, Belknap Co., New Hampshire.
1 children: Cynthia Louisa.
(9) Cynthia Louisa Wolcott9 (Alexander Simon Wolcott8, Alexander Wolcott7, Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1834 Bridgeport, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesCYNTHIA had a guardian, Humphrey Phelps of New York City, appointed for her at age 13 in New York City, having no father or guardian, but owning property at Stamford, Connecticut.
(7) Lucy Wolcott7 (Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 JUN 1780 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 28 JAN 1782 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
(7) Mary Wolcott7 (Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 DEC 1781 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 4 DEC 1832 .

(9) Martha Pitkins Manwaring9 (Simon Wolcott Manwaring8, Mary Wolcott7, Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 18 AUG 1849 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. Augustus Foster, b. ABT 1845 , d. .
(8) Robert Alexander Manwaring8 (Mary Wolcott7, Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 AUG 1811 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 1 SEP 1890 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
m. 15 MAY 1845 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Ellen Barber, b. 21 DEC 1821 Groton, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 24 NOV 1903 Washington, District of Columbia.
1 children: William Wolcott.
(9) William Wolcott Manwaring9 (Robert Alexander Manwaring8, Mary Wolcott7, Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 MAY 1847 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
(7) Lucy Wolcott7 (Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 31 OCT 1783 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 10 AUG 1852 .
m. 25 NOV 1802 Francis Drake, b. 8 JAN 1781 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 21 MAR 1811 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
3 children: Elizur Wolcott, Elizabeth, Frances Catharine.
(8) Elizur Wolcott Drake8 (Lucy Wolcott7, Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 SEP 1803 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 9 FEB 1860 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 14 APR 1830 East Windsor, Windsor Co., Vermont, Eveline S. Rollo, b. 19 JAN 1809 of East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 20 OCT 1882 .
4 children: Ellen E., Albert Waldo, Albert Waldo, Charles Francis.

(7) Elizabeth Wolcott7 (Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 10 JAN 1788 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
(6) Simon Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 AUG 1747 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 APR 1809 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesSIMON was a physician at New London, Connecticut. For several years he was Secretary of the County Medical Society. He served a surgeon of the 6th Connecticut Regiment during the Revolutionary War from 20 May 1775 until 21 December 1775 and in Col. Guy's Regiment from June to December 1776. His house and barn on "The Bank" at New London, were burned by the British during the war. In 1791 he was compensated for loss of property at New London , valued at 1,083L, by a grant of land in the Western Reserve of Ohio. In 1790 his family at New London consisted of 2 males over 16, 1 male under 16, and 8 females.
m. 8 NOV 1798 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Charlotte Woodbridge, b. 26 DEC 1761 , d. 1 DEC 1831 .
1 children: Frances Caroline.
(7) Frances Caroline Wolcott7 (Simon Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 FEB 1803 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. George Stillman Robbins, b. 25 MAY 1796 Sandisfield, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 JAN 1886 .
(6) Esther Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 JUL 1749 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 28 NOV 1841 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesESTHER was interested in genealogy, and collected information about the Wolcott family.
m. 6 JAN 1785 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Samuel Treat, b. 6 JUL 1752 Wethersfield, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 29 APR 1795 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

(6) George Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 23 MAY 1751 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 OCT 1751 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) George Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 OCT 1753 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 31 JAN 1822 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesGEORGE was a Representative for the town of Windsor at the General Assembly. In 1790, his family at Windsor consisted of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females. He moved to Saybrook, Connecticut, in 1804, where he was Surveyor of the Port.

6 children: Henry Lay, Mary W., Caroline H., William Mather, Bethel Mather, Julia Frances.
(9) Henry Lay Bliss9 (Henry Bliss8, Mary Wolcott7, George Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 FEB 1843 ,, New York, d. .
NotesHENRY enlisted in the Union Army during Civil War as a private and afterwards was made a Lieutenant and then Captain, retaining the latter as a title. On June 14, 1870 at Chicago, he was reported to be living in a boarding house and working as a painter.
m. 22 MAY 1873 Laura E. Lane, b. 19 MAY 1850 Wooster, Wayne Co., Ohio, d. .
3 children: William Lane, Henry W., Laura F..
(10) William Lane Bliss10 (Henry Lay Bliss9, Henry Bliss8, Mary Wolcott7, George Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 FEB 1875 La Grange, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 8 MAR 1948 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesWilliam served with an Illinois volunteer regiment during the Spanish-American War under the leadership of the father of the famed General Douglas MacArthur. He then enlisted in the 11th Philippine Veteran Volunteer Calvalry and served in the Camarines of the Philippine archipelago. He received an honorable discharge. He entered the newspaper business and eventually worked for "The Chicago Tribune, The Chicago Inter-Ocean, The Kansas City Post, The Denver Post and The Denver Times". After many evenful years of reporting, he became labor editor for "The Chicago Herald and Examiner", and then edited various other labor newspapers. In 1937, he bacame assistant editor of the VOICE, a labor paper for cement, lime, gypsum and allied workers, a position held until 1947.

Spouse NotesELIJAH graduated from Yale College in 1791.

NotesHENRY died at sea.
(7) William Frederick Wolcott7 (George Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 JUN 1788 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Agawam, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
NotesWILLIAM was a farmer at West Springfield, Massachusetts, and a Justice of the Peace. In 1860 he was at Agawam, Massachusetts, with children Martha, Hellen, and Alexander.
m. 30 NOV 1815 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Lois Bryant, b. 1 MAY 1787 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 14 FEB 1843 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.

NotesMARTHA and her sister, Helen, and brother, Alexander, lived together at Agawan, Massachusetts, in 1880, all unmarried.

NotesWILLIAM was a farmer at Agawan, age 38, when he elisted 2 Sept. 1862 as a private in I Co., 46th Massachusetts Inf. Regt.. He wasa farmer at Agawam, Massachusetts, in 1860, with Elizabeth M., Frederick C., and William B. Woolcott.
m. 26 APR 1848 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Elizabeth M. Cooper, b. 1827 ,, Massachusetts, d. .
3 children: Frederick C., William B., William Henry.

NotesHelen was an Army nurse.
(8) Alexander Bryant Wolcott8 (William Frederick Wolcott7, George Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 12 AUG 1828 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 APR 1829 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
(8) Alexander Wolcott8 (William Frederick Wolcott7, George Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 26 APR 1830 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. JAN 1904 Agawam, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
NotesALEXANDER was a farmer at Agawam, Massachusetts, in 1880. His sisters, Martha and Helen, lived with him.
(7) Elizabeth Wolcott7 (George Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 14 NOV 1790 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(6) Christopher Drake Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1 OCT 1754 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 APR 1821 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesCHRISTOPHER studied medicine with his father. He was a surgeon's mate in Col. Erastus Wolcott's regiment from December 1775 to January 1781 during the Revolutionary War. He was granted land at Enosburg, Franklin County, New Hampshire, for his military service. He was a physician at Windsor, Connecticut, one of the founders of the Hartford County Medical Society, and served as a Representative to the General Assembly. He lived in his father's house after his father's death. In 1790 he was at Windsor with a family of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females.
m. 1 AUG 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Lucy Parsons, b. 3 AUG 1762 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 MAR 1804 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
6 children: Laura, Elizabeth, Christopher Columbus, Laura, Elizabeth, Philip.
(7) Laura Wolcott7 (Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 MAY 1783 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 AUG 1789 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Elizabeth Wolcott7 (Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 JAN 1785 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 MAY 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Christopher Columbus Wolcott7 (Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 JUN 1787 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 18 DEC 1853 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
NotesCHRISTOPHER lived at Wolcottville, Connecticut, where he was a Justice of the Peace and Representative to the Connecticut State Legislature. In 1833 he moved to Steubenville, Ohio, where he engaged in woolen manufacturing. He was a visitor at the Steubenville Female Seminary where his daughter, Caroline, was a student, in 1836-7. The 1837 business directory for Beaver Co., Pennsylvania, has at Fallston: "C. C. Wolcott has a large factory for the manufacturing of Jeans upon a very extensive scale with splendid machinery, unsurpassed for excellency and beauty by any in any part of the country." He operated the Fallston factory until 1850 or later.
m. 18 NOV 1818 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Susan Blinn, b. 14 AUG 1795 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 10 APR 1859 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
7 children: Christopher Parsons, Samuel Merwin, Henry Philip "Harry", Frederick Halsey, Susan Maria, Caroline Matilda, Laura Elizabeth.
(8) Christopher Parsons Wolcott8 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 DEC 1820 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 4 APR 1863 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesCHRISTOPHER attended Kenyon College in 1839, and graduated from Jefferson College at Washington, Pennsylvania, in 1840 at the age of 20. He read law in the office of Tappan & Stanton. Tappan became U. S. Senator from Ohio, and Edwin Stanton became Secretary of War. Christopher was admitted to the Bar in 1843, and established a law practice at Akron in 1846. He built a large home on West Market St. in Akron, which was destroyed by fire in 1933. He was appointed Attorney-General for the State of Ohio in 1856 and served until 1861. His most famous case was the Wellington Fugitive Slave case. He journied to Virginia to ask Gov. Wise to spare the life of the abolitionist, John Brown, whose home was at Kent, Portage Co., Ohio. He became Judge Advocate General in 1861. In May of 1862 he was appointed Assistant Secretary of War, under his brother-in-law, Edwin Stanton, Secretary of War. He held this position at the time of his death. His brother-in-law often visited his widowed sister at Gambier to rest from his greuling schedule, He was so unobtrusive that the neighbors usually did not know he was there. When his two nephews, Darwin and Merwin, were in College after the war, Stanton spoke affectionately of his college days at Kenyon College from which he received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree..
m. 18 APR 1844 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, Pamphila Stanton, b. 20 FEB 1827 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 8 FEB 1899 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesPAMPHILA was living with her son, Darwin, in Washington, D. C., in 1880.
5 children: Christopher Darwin, Christopher Columbus, Samuel Merwin, William Merwin, Darwin Stanton.
(9) Christopher Darwin Wolcott9 (Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 SEP 1846 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. INFANT .
(9) Christopher Columbus Wolcott9 (Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 25 SEP 1847 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1899 Vallejo, Solano Co., California.
NotesCHRISTOPHER was a member of the Founders and Patriots of America. In 1897 he was Deputy Governor of the organization. Born September 25, 1846, died April 5, 1902. Columbus C. Wolcott purchased 160 acres of land at Humbolt Co., California in 1884. Christopher C. Wolcott registered to vote at Vallejo, California, in 1890.
m. 8 FEB 1872 Elizabeth McCrae, b. ,, Virginia, d. .
2 children: Christopher Stanton, Cornella.
(10) Christopher Stanton Wolcott10 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 AUG 1874 ,, Virginia, d. 1928 Hornell, Steuben Co., New York.
NotesChristopher graduated from the University of Pennsylvania

Robert D. Wolcott (1888-1947), was my mother's grandfather. We believe that his parents were William Merwin Wolcott (b. 1848) and his wife Caroline Delange (b. 1857). They were married 16 Apr 1881 but I do not know where. A 1900 Federal Census Report puts Robert D. Wolcott as the son to a Caroline B Wolcott along with a sibling Helen D S Wolcott (his sister). It also states that their father was born in Ohio. Unfortunately, there is no mention of William Merwin Wolcott in this or any census report. The same census report lists Caroline B. Wolcott as a widow so if William Merwin Wolcott was their father then he passed before 1900. Helen Wolcott later went on to be a Broadway actress and stared in a few "talkies", which is what they called movies when they first came out with sound. Robert Wolcott later married Amy Glezen on 5 Nov 1919 and they had three children; Robert G. Wolcott (My mother's father) 1920-1955, Helen B. Wolcott (living) and Donna Jane Wolcott (living).
m. 1872 Sarah Harding "Sallie" Crothers, b. 20 AUG 1848 , d. 5 JAN 1873 .
(9) William Merwin Wolcott9 (Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 DEC 1849 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. ABT 1890 .
NotesWILLIAM attended college. He apparently died shortly after his second marriage when his wife is listed as a widow.

1900 Denver CO:
Caroline D Wolcott 43, b. PA Oct 1856, bakery
Robert D Wolcott 12, b. CO Feb 1888
Helen D S Wolcott 7, b. Co Sept 1892

1908 Denver CO
Mrs. Caroline D. Wolcott
Miss Helen S. Wolcott, student
Robert D.Wolcott, meter reader

1910 Los Angeles CA
Carolyn Wolcott 54 b. PA own income
Helen Wolcott 17 b. CO legal stenographer
Annie S Dornberg 31 roomer ,garment fitter




Robert D. Wolcott (1888-1947), was my mother's grandfather. We believe that his parents were William Merwin Wolcott (b. 1848) and his wife Caroline Delange (b. 1857). They were married 16 Apr 1881 but I do not know where. A 1900 Federal Census Report puts Robert D. Wolcott as the son to a Caroline B Wolcott along with a sibling Helen D S Wolcott (his sister). It also states that their father was born in Ohio. Unfortunately, there is no mention of William Merwin Wolcott in this or any census report. The same census report lists Caroline B. Wolcott as a widow so if William Merwin Wolcott was their father then he passed before 1900. Helen Wolcott later went on to be a Broadway actress and stared in a few "talkies", which is what they called movies when they first came out with sound. Robert Wolcott later married Amy Glezen on 5 Nov 1919 and they had three children; Robert G. Wolcott (My mother's father) 1920-1955, Helen B. Wolcott (living) and Donna Jane Wolcott (living).
m. 16 APR 1881 Caroline Delange, b. 4 OCT 1856 Pittsburgh, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, d. .
Spouse NotesCAROLINE was at Pittsburg, Pennsylvania, in 1860 with her mother Louisa Delange 38, born Massachusetts, Julia 7, Caroline 4, and Frank E. 2, all born Pennsylvania. Caroline's granddaughter, Donna, said she adopted Robert when a friend who worked as a maid in a wealthy family asked her to do so, saying that a daughter of that family got pregnant and her parents opposed marriage. She also said Caroline later adopted Helen. Caroline D. Wolcott, widow, working in a bakery, was at Denver, Colorado, in 1900, with Robert D. and Helen D. S. Wolcott. The census record says she and her father were born in Pennsylvania, and her mother in Massachusetts, and her childrens father was born in Ohio. In 1910 Caroline Wolcott, 59, self and father born Pennsylvania, mother born Massachusetts, was at Los Angeles with "own income", with daughter Helen Wolcott, self and father born Colorado, stenographer.
2 children: Robert Delange, Helen Delange Stanton.
(10) Robert Delange Wolcott10 (William Merwin Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 FEB 1888 Denver, Arapahoe Co., Colorado, d. 16 DEC 1947 Los Angeles, Los Angeles Co., California.
NotesROBERT lived with his uncle, Frank E. Delange 52, machinist, at Denver, Colorado, in 1910, with both parents born Pennsylvania. Frank was at Pittsburg in 1880, and at Denver in 1900. His daughter, Donna, said that her mother told her that a friend of Robert's mother worked as a maid in a wealthy family who refused to allow their pregnant daughter to marry the father of her child. The baby was taken in and raised by Caroline.

1918 Draft Registration
Robert D Wolcott 29, b. 15 Feb 1888 Denver CO, lives Los Angeles, Imperial Irigation District, single, served in California Artillery 7 yrs., medium height, slender, blue eyes, light brown hair.
(10) Helen Delange Stanton Wolcott10 (William Merwin Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 SEP 1893 ,, Colorado, d. .
NotesHELEN was a stenographer at Los Angeles in 1910. She became an acress in early silent films, 1914-1916. In 1919 she filed for a passport to travel to France with the Overseas Theatre League, giving her name as Helen Stanton Wolcott and her father born at Sewickley, Iowa, current location unknown.

Helen Stanton Wolcott
Birth Date: 20 Sep 1893
Birth Place: Denver, Colorado
Age: 25
Passport Issue Date: 11 Apr 1919 for YMCA entertainment work, Overdeas Theatre League.
Passport Includes a Photo: Yes
Residence: New York City, New York, actress
Father Name: Merwin Wolcott
Father's Birth Location: Sewickley, Iowa
(9) Darwin Stanton Wolcott9 (Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 JUL 1851 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 15 FEB 1927 Sewickley, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesDARWIN attended Kenyon College, and was was at College, Ohio, in 1870. He was employed by the United States Coast Survey as an emgineer for 5 or 6 years, and then worked for the Patent Office in Washington D. C.. He moved to Pittsburg in 1883 and in partnership with George H. Christy, established a law office. He was an attorney at Pittsburg in the 1890s and assisted Reginald Fessening in registering patents on his inventions for radio broadcasting. He helped Fessening find financial backers for setting up the National Electric Signaling Co. and was one of the principal shareholders in the company. The company sent the first two-way wireless communication across the Atlantic and produced the first radio broadcast program in 1906. In 1910 he established his own practice. He settled at Sedgewickley, where he was a member of the Episcopal Church.

1910 Sewickley PA:
Darwin S Wolcott 54, b. OH widower, lawyer, patent attorney
Darwin S Wolcott Jr 32. b. Dist of Columbia, office mgr., steel works
Catherine R Wolcott 28, b. Dist. of Columbia
Christopher P Wolcott 26, b. Dist of Columbia, Supt. Tin mill
Mary L Wolcott 21, b. PA
Robert W Wolcott 17, b. PA
Evelyn M Wolcott 15, b. PA
Kate Stepanczk 19, servant
m. 23 JUL 1876 Winchester, Frederick Co., Virginia, Evelyn Brent Reily, b. 27 OCT 1856 Winchester, Frederick Co., Virginia, d. JUN 1902 .
Spouse NotesEVELYN was moved from Union Cemetery, Steubenville, to Sewickley 9 April 1927, to lie beside her husband.
7 children: Wilhelmina, Darwin Stanton, Katharine Riley, Christopher Parsons, Mary Louise Hutchinson, Robert Wilson, Evelyn Moore.
(10) Wilhelmina Wolcott10 (Darwin Stanton Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 MAY 1877 Pittsburgh, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, d. .
(10) Darwin Stanton Wolcott10 (Darwin Stanton Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 JAN 1879 Washington, District of Columbia, d. 7 NOV 1962 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesDARWIN was vice president of Lukens Steel Corp., Coatesville, Pennsylvania. He was a member of the Wolcott Society in 1914, residing at Pittsburg, and Society vice-president for Western Pennsylvania in 1916.

"My grandfather supposedly ran away from the orphanage and lived on the streets selling newspapers for a while. A man named Mr. Wolcott took an interest in him and helped him get a job in a company that Mr. Wolcott owned. My grandfather worked for him until he was 15 years old. My grandfather and grandmother lived in Pittsburgh and had 7 children. My father is Darwin Wolcott. Meloney. My father's was named after the Mr. Wolcott that helped my Grandfather. I think I remember being told that Mr. Wolcott owned a steel mill, I am not too sure about that though."

This story does not conform to his father's biography in "History of Pittsburgh.


DARWIN STANTON WOLCOTT, long a leader among the patent law attorneys of Pittsburgh, can look back upon more than thirty years of successful practice
in the metropolis. Mr. Wolcott is a man of varied experience and capabilities, the years of his early manhood having been spent in the service of the United States Coast Survey.

Christopher Parsens Wolcott, father of Darwin Stanton Wolcott, was a distinguished member of the bar. For a time he filled the office of Attorney-General of
Ohio, and during the Civil War served as Assistant Secretary of War under Edwin M. Stanton in the cabinet of President Lincoln. Mr. Wolcott married Pamphila Stanton, sister of the renowned Secretary of War Stanton.

Darwin Stanton Wolcott, son of Christopher Parsens and Pamphila (Stanton) Wolcott, was bom July 21, 1851, in Akron, Ohio. He received his preparatory education in public and private schools, afterward entering Kenyon College. His first employment was as
engineer in the United States Coast Survey, this initial period of activity being filled with experience which proved valuable to him in later life. At the end of five
or six years Mr. Wolcott resigned his position, and for the following five years was employed in the United States Patent Office. In September, 1883, be came to Pittsburgh, and in association with George H. Christy entered upon the practice of patent law. Since 1910 Mr. Wolcott has practiced alone. He devotes himself
exclusively to patent law and was not long in laying the foundation of the reputation which has since steadily increased and has long been absolutely assured.

In politics Mr. Wolcott is a Republican with progressive tendencies, in this as in everything else being singularly fairminded and open to conviction. Ever alive to the best interests of his city and State as well as to those of the nation he aids in the promotion of those interests untrammelled by partisan considerations.
His countenance gives evidence of the liberality of sentiment and breadth of view by which he is always characterized, and his personality and manner are those
of the astute lawyer and the true gentleman. He belongs to the Pittsburgh Press Club and the Pittsburgh Athletic Association, and is a member of the Sewickley
Protestant Episcopal Church.

Mr. Wolcott married, in July, 1876, Evelyn Brent Rcilly, daughter of James Reilly, of Winchester, Va., and the following children were bom to them: Dar- win Stanton, Jr., Christopher P., Robert W., Wilhelmina, wife of Robert H. Wright, of San Francisco, Cal; Katherine L., Mary L. H., and Evelyn M. Mrs. Wolcott, a most lovely and estimable woman, and a member of the Women's Club of Sewickley, passed away
in June, 1902.

1918 Draft Registration:
Darwin Stanton Wolcott, b. 2 Jan 1879, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, medium height and stature, partly illegible
(10) Katharine Riley Wolcott10 (Darwin Stanton Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 JUN 1881 Washington, District of Columbia, d. JAN 1982 Washington, District of Columbia.
(10) Christopher Parsons Wolcott10 (Darwin Stanton Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 JAN 1883 Washington, District of Columbia, d. 30 JUL 1931 .

1918 Draft Registration:
Christopher Parsons Wolcott 35, b. 23 Jan 1883 Chicago, Cook, Illinois, foreman, film service, Famous Players Lasky Corp., wife Martha Hagen Wolcott, tall, medium build, grey eyes, Brown hair.
(10) Mary Louise Hutchinson Wolcott10 (Darwin Stanton Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 SEP 1888 Sewickley, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, d. 23 OCT 1972 .
(10) Robert Wilson Wolcott10 (Darwin Stanton Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 23 APR 1892 Sedwickley, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, d. 30 JAN 1982 Bryn Mawr, Delaware Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesROBERT was attending Lehigh University when WWI broke out. He enlisted in the Navy's Aviation Corp, and became a Lieutenant. After discharge he worked for Bethlehem Fabricators, and in 1922 was employed by the Lukens Steel Co. of Coatesville, Pennsylvania, becoming president of the company in 1925, succeeding his father-in-law, A. F. Lukens. In 1932 he lived at West Chester, Pennsylvania. Robert held this position until 1949 when he became President of the Board of Directors. Robert was the author of "A Woman in Steel - Rebecca Lukens 1794-1854, published in 1940. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1949 as member #459, residing at Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania.
(10) Evelyn Moore Wolcott10 (Darwin Stanton Wolcott9, Christopher Parsons Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 JUN 1893 Sewickley, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, d. 11 APR 1929 Sewickley, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania.
(8) Samuel Merwin Wolcott8 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 JUN 1822 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 3 AUG 1848 .
(8) Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 4 FEB 1824 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 11 MAY 1868 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
NotesHENRY P. Wolcott of Steubenville, Ohio, attended the Western Reserve College 1840-41. He was a woolen manufacturer at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1850. He was at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1860, with Sarah, Susan, Harry, Laura, Jessie, and Carrie. Jessie Wolcott Cool is married inthe same cemetery lot.
m. 26 JAN 1847 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, Sarah Ann Allen, b. 22 FEB 1827 Ravenna, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 1904 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesSARAH was at Steubebville, Ohio, in 1870, with Laura, Jessie, and Carrie. She and her children, Jesse and Carrie, were living at Steubenville in 1880. In 1900 she lived with her daughter, Laura. Ann and Thomas Allen, possibly her parents, are buried in the same cemetery lot.
6 children: Susan Maria, Henry Frederick, Laura Elizabeth, David Jesse "Jesse", Caroline Andrews "Carrie", Henry Allen.
(9) Susan Maria Wolcott9 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 12 JUL 1848 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 23 APR 1918 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesSUSAN was visiting her second husband, who was a resident in the Chicago Home for Insurables since 1916, when she was injured in an fatal elevator accident.
m. 17 NOV 1868 , Jefferson Co., Ohio, Ryan Welsh Allison, b. 19 AUG 1844 , d. 27 NOV 1877 .
2 children: William Rea, Henry Wolcott.
(10) William Rea Allison10 (Susan Maria Wolcott9, Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 AUG 1870 , d. .
(10) Henry Wolcott Allison10 (Susan Maria Wolcott9, Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 18 SEP 1872 , d. .
(9) Susan Maria Wolcott9 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 12 JUL 1848 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 23 APR 1918 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesSUSAN was visiting her second husband, who was a resident in the Chicago Home for Insurables since 1916, when she was injured in an fatal elevator accident.
m. 1 MAR 1892 Charles Pierson Chesebro, b. 11 JUL 1845 Canandaigua, Ontario Co., New York, d. Saint Louis, Saint Louis Co., Missouri.
Spouse NotesCHARLES served in the Union Army. He was an accountant for the Wabash Railroad at St. Louis, Missouri.
1 children: George Latimer.
