(10) Lucy Wolcott10 (Henry Frederick Wolcott9, Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 10 NOV 1875 , d. .
(9) Laura Elizabeth Wolcott9 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 MAY 1854 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 24 NOV 1924 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesLAURA was a school teacher at Steubenville in 1872. She was a widow at Steubenville in 1910, living with son Allyn W. Matlack, who worked in an iron mill.

the
death of Mrs. Laura W. Matlack,
former well known nnd highly
esteemed resident of this city,
which occurred at a Toledo hospital
early this morning. Mrs
Matlack underwent a surgical operation
Sunday evening, and was
improving nicely when pneumonia
set in, death resulting after only
a few short hours of suffering.
The remains will arrive in this
o'clock, with Father Sidener officiating.
Interment will take
place in tho Union cemetery.
Mrs Matlack was born and
raised in Steubenvllle, a member
of one of the oldest and most
highly esteemed familles in the
valley. She was educated in the
public schools of the city and was
a graduate of the Steubenvllle
high school. She was the daughter
of the late Henry nnd Sarah
Allen Wolcott, and the wife of the
late David W. Matlack, Who preceded
her in death in 1907. She
was a member of the Episcopal
Church from early girlhood, and
an active worker in all religious
matters. For the past eight
years She has been making her
home with grandchildren in Toledo.
Surviving the loss of loving
and devoted mother are two children,
Harry W., of Grinnell, Iowa, and A. Wolcott of this city. One daughter, Helen, , with whose
chiidren, Mrs. Matlack has been
making her home, preceded her in
death. Two sisters, Mrs; J . H;
Tlmberlake of this, city and Mrs,
Jessie W. Cook Of Spokane,
Wash., also survive.
m. 12 JUL 1873 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, David W. Matlack, b. 25 AUG 1848 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 27 APR 1907 .
Spouse NotesDAVID was a school teacher at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1850-1900. In 1895 he was elected president of the Eastern Ohio Teacher's Assocoation.
3 children: Henry William "Harry", Wolcott Allyn "Allyn", Helen.
(10) Henry William "Harry" Matlack10 (Laura Elizabeth Wolcott9, Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 29 OCT 1875 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 8 OCT 1936 .
NotesHARRY becme a music professor at Grinnell College in 1901 His wife was his student there. He was Dean of Men at Grinnel College, Iowa. In 1922 he was appointed alumni secretary of the college. All six of his children attended Grinnel.
(10) Wolcott Allyn "Allyn" Matlack10 (Laura Elizabeth Wolcott9, Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 10 MAY 1879 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 12 OCT 1926 Wheeling, Ohio Co., West Virginia.
NotesALLYN graduated from Oberlin College and the University of Ohio. He worked for the La Belle Iron Works, which later became part of the Wheeling Steel Corporation for 25 years, where he was manager of Compensation. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1918 as member #27, residing at Steubenville OH.
(10) Helen Matlack10 (Laura Elizabeth Wolcott9, Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. MAR 1885 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. .
(9) David Jesse "Jesse" Wolcott9 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 25 NOV 1856 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. ABT 1935 .
(9) Caroline Andrews "Carrie" Wolcott9 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 JUN 1859 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 26 DEC 1943 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
NotesCARRIE was a school teacher at Steubenville in 1880 and 1885, and was living there in 1914.Philip Wolcott Timberlake and Richard Henry Timberlake of Steubenville attended the 1911 Wolcott reunion and were probably her sons. Also attending from Steubenville was Rev. William Martin Sidener, possibly another relative.
m. 2 FEB 1887 Gambier, Knox Co., Ohio, John Henry Timberlake, b. 21 OCT 1856 Cincinnati, Hamilton Co., Ohio, d. 27 SEP 1949 Gambier, Knox Co., Ohio.
2 children: Philip Wolcott, Richard Henry.
(10) Philip Wolcott Timberlake10 (Caroline Andrews "Carrie" Wolcott9, Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 JUL 1895 , d. 11 MAY 1957 Mansfield, Richland Co., Ohio.
NotesPHILIP Timberlake served in the army during World War I , and afterward taught English and History for two years at his alma mater, Wells High School. He then returned to academic study at Princeton, and earned his Master's degree in 1924. Two years later, in 1926, Timberlake completed his doctorate, and afterward declined a position at Princeton to return to Kenyon. was an instructor at Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio. The Philip Wolcott Timberlake Memorial Prize given by Kenyon College for the best English scholar is named for him. While at Kenyon, Timberlake remained a prominent English professor for 31 years. He was the Charles Pettit McIlvaine Professor of English and was Secretary of the College Faculty. At the time of his death on May 11, 1957 he was the Head of the English Department.

He favored Old English and Middle English literature courses and was known for his Shakespeare courses, but also conducted instructional composition classes for freshmen. His Chaucer classes were well liked among the student body, which nicknamed the popular professor "Timbuck". Timberlake's was a published author whose work, prose, drama, and poetry, was featured in the Kenyon Review, The Christian Science Monitor, The Modern Language Journal, Collier's Encyclopedia, and more. He also served as editor for the Sigma Pi publication The Emerald during the years between 1920 and 1929. For a time he also acted as faculty advisor to The Kenyon Collegian. His major works include The Feminine Ending in English Blank Verse and an essay on Milton and Euripides, which was published in Studies in Dramatic Literature. His one-act play Love's Labor, co-written with Robert Ball, was performed at Kenyon and the University of Colorado, and broadcast from the University of Wisconsin.

At the age of 61, Dr. Timberlake suffered a fatal stroke. His memorial service was held at the Church of the Holy Spirit on Kenyon's campus.

He and his brother attended the 1911 Wolcott Society reunion.
(10) Richard Henry Timberlake10 (Caroline Andrews "Carrie" Wolcott9, Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 MAR 1893 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 9 JUN 1978 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.

(9) Caroline Wolcott Andrews9 (Caroline Matilda Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 31 MAY 1867 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. JAN 1934 New York City, New York.
m. 30 APR 1891 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Richard Buckminster Fuller, b. 13 FEB 1861 Cambridge, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 12 JUL 1910 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesRICHARD and son, Wolcott, lived at 169 E. 78th St., New York City, in 1930, and were listed in the Social Register.
2 children: Richard Buckminster "Buckminster", Wolcott.
(10) Richard Buckminster "Buckminster" Fuller10 (Caroline Wolcott Andrews9, Caroline Matilda Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 12 JUL 1895 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 1 JUL 1983 Los Angeles, Los Angeles Co., California.
NotesRICHARD was an inventor, futurist, and philosopher. He designed the geodesic dome linking triangles into a strong and lighweight sphere. He wrote 25 books and lectured on college campuses into his eighties. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1979 as life member #1199, residing at Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
(10) Wolcott Fuller10 (Caroline Wolcott Andrews9, Caroline Matilda Wolcott8, Christopher Columbus Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1898 , d. DEC 1959 .
NotesWOLCOTT was a publicity man for General Electric. He was in the 1930 New York City Social Blue Book.

(8) James Christopher Marshall8 (Elizabeth Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 18 SEP 1818 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 JAN 1888 .
(8) John Randolph Marshall8 (Elizabeth Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 JUL 1822 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 JUL 1891 Dublin, Franklin Co., Ohio.
NotesJOHN was one of the first Doctors in Dublin, Ohio. He served as an officer in the Mexican War in 1846, in Company I, 3rd Regiment, Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regt. He was an Ohio state representative, and a contributor to the Columbus Record. He is said to have discovered a cure for black diptheria and for cholera. In 1998 his doctors office was still standing.
m. 29 AUG 1852 Worthington, Franklin Co., Ohio, Louise Marie Lusk, b. 18 AUG 1832 Worthington, Franklin Co., Ohio, d. 11 JUN 1873 Dublin, Franklin Co., Ohio.

(8) Lucy Ann Marshall8 (Elizabeth Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 14 NOV 1827 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1903 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 25 NOV 1850 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Ellsworth Newberry Phelps, b. 9 FEB 1826 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. JAN 1913 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesELLSWORTH enlisted in Co. A, 22nd Connecticut Inf. Regt. in 1862, and was elected Captain of the company. He recruited 130 men and was appointed Lt. Col. of the Regt. He was a Whig and later a Republican, an Episcopalian, justice of the peace, and grand juror. He was assistant civil engineer on the Connecticut River, surveying much of Hartford County. He also had a farm.
2 children: Samuel Ellsworth, Annie Marshall.
(9) Samuel Ellsworth Phelps9 (Lucy Ann Marshall8, Elizabeth Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 JUN 1852 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesSAMUEL was elected Town Clerk of Windsor 5 October 1885. He was the postmaster at Windsor.
m. 28 MAR 1871 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Adella J. Filley, b. 9 MAY 1853 , d. .

(8) Frances Wolcott8 (Philip Wolcott7, Christopher Drake Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 8 APR 1818 , d. .
m. 1839 , Hartford Co., Connecticut, Ralph Ralston, b. 1818 , Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(6) Christopher Drake Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1 OCT 1754 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 APR 1821 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesCHRISTOPHER studied medicine with his father. He was a surgeon's mate in Col. Erastus Wolcott's regiment from December 1775 to January 1781 during the Revolutionary War. He was granted land at Enosburg, Franklin County, New Hampshire, for his military service. He was a physician at Windsor, Connecticut, one of the founders of the Hartford County Medical Society, and served as a Representative to the General Assembly. He lived in his father's house after his father's death. In 1790 he was at Windsor with a family of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females.
m. 26 SEP 1806 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Amy Gillett, b. 30 JUL 1770 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 JUL 1835 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

(8) Sophia Ellen Hackley8 (Sophia Griswold7, Mary Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 25 JUL 1819 ,, New York, d. 27 AUG 1904 ,, New York.
m. 30 AUG 1843 Utica, Oneida Co., New York, David Parish Barhydt, b. 16 APR 1816 Ogdensburg, St. Lawrence Co., New York, d. 13 FEB 1908 New York City, New York.
1 children: Kate Wolcott.
(9) Kate Wolcott Barhydt9 (Sophia Ellen Hackley8, Sophia Griswold7, Mary Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 MAR 1848 , d. 1913 .
Notes KATE was Wolcott Society vice-president for New York in 1909-10, residing at Mt. Vernon New York. After her death, her husband continued to be a member.
m. 12 APR 1883 Herman Drisler, b. 1857 ,, New York, d. .
Spouse NotesHERMAN Drisler, of Mt. Vernon, New York, was a member of the Wolcott Society 1909-17. He was on the Society finance committee in 1909. He is probably the Herman Drisler, age 3, born New York, who was with Elizabeth Drisler 40, born New York, at Northampton, New Jersey, in 1860. In 1880 he was a lawyer at New York City, age 23, living with his father, Henry Drisler, a professor.
(6) Alexander Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 SEP 1758 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 JUN 1828 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1778 and practiced law in Windsor, where he was a Representative to the General Assembly for five sessions, 1796-1801. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. He had warrant of 50,000 acres on south side of Powell's Muntain on Guest's River, and 100,000 acres on the west bank of Tottery Creek in 1795. In 1796 he sold a grant of 100,000 acres on the East Branch of the Big Sandy River in Russell Co., Virginia, to Ebenezer Fitch Bissell. In 1799 he held 12,500 acres of land in Grayson Co., Virginia. His land holding claims were disputed due to disagreements between Virginia and Kentucky over their borders, and "Wolcotters" became a term for people with dubious land claims. Alexander Smyth of Wythe Co., Virginia, contracted with Alexander Wolcott of Connecticut to survey 850,000 acres of land. An 1800 deed conveyed 1,034 acres of land from Alexander Smyth to Alexander Wolcott of Windsor, Connecticut, for 434 dollars. Alexander was at Middleton, Connecticut in 1800, were he was a Justice of the Peace. He was Collector of Customs for Middletown there from 1801 until his death in 1828, when he was succeeded by his eldest son. He was one of the early manufacturers of woolen cloth in this country. Alexander was one of the leaders of the Republican Party of Connecticut. He was nominated for the U.S. Supreme Court by President Madison in 1810, but the nomination failed to get the approval of the Senate for political reasons, 24 to 9. It was said "But he was widely unpopular as revenue collectors tend to be". He was a member of the State Constitutional Convention in 1818.
m. 22 SEP 1785 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Frances Burbank, b. 1765 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 17 JAN 1800 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
4 children: Frances, Henry, Alexander, Mary Ann.
(7) Frances Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 AUG 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. AFT 1835 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
m. 2 MAR 1804 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Thomas Homans, b. ABT 1780 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1805 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
1 children: Frances.
(8) Frances Homans8 (Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1804 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1865 .
(7) Frances Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 AUG 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. AFT 1835 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
m. 5 JAN 1806 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Arthur William Magill, b. 3 AUG 1783 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1855 Ottawa, LaSalle Co., Illinois.
7 children: Juliette Augusta, William A., Mary Ann Wolcott, Arthur, Henry Wolcott, Alexander Wolcot, Julian.
(8) Juliette Augusta Magill8 (Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 11 SEP 1806 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 17 SEP 1870 Amagansett, Suffolk Co., New York.
NotesJULIETTE was called "Chicago's First Author". She attended Emma Willard's Scholl at Troy, New York, and her uncle, Alexander Wolcott, taught her Latin and other languages. She accompanied her husband into the wilderness of Wisconsin, Michigan, and Illinois. Her best known book, published in 1856, was entitled "Waubun, the Early Days in the Northwest". It was a story of her experiences living in the wilderness from 1830 to 1833.
m. 9 AUG 1827 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, John Harris Kinzie, b. 7 JUL 1803 Sandwich,, Canada, d. 21 JUN 1865 Pittsburgh, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania.
Spouse NotesJOHN came with his father to what is now Chicago, in 1803. They were among the first settlers there. John moved to Detroit, Michiigan in 1816, and was appointed Indian Agent for the Winnebagos there in 1828. From 1830 to 1833, he travelled throught Wisconsin, Michigan, and Illinois, distributing blankets, cloth, guns, Kettles, traps, and other things to the Indians as a representative of the U.S. government. He signed as a witness to a treaty between the U. S. government and the Chippewa Indian Nation in 1833, and is listed in an attachment to the treaty as rustee for money owed under the treaty to Jean Bt. Miranda, Jane Miranda, Rosetta Miranda, and Thomas Miranda, and for Josett Ouilmot. In another attachment to the treaty, John H. Kinzie and Ellen M. Wolcott were named as owed $5,000 each. On returning to Chicago in 1834, he became President of the Board of Trustees of the village. He was appointed Registrar of Public Lands at Chicago in 1841, and Paymaster of the U.S. Army in 1861. In 1865 he was brevetted Lt. Colonel in the U.S. Army. He built the First Episcopal Church in Chicago.
7 children: Eleanor Lytle "Nellie", Wolcott, John Harris, Arthur, Julian, Frank, George.
(9) Eleanor Lytle "Nellie" Kinzie9 (Juliette Augusta Magill8, Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1835 Fort Dearborn, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 22 FEB 1917 Amagansett, Suffolk Co., New York.
NotesEleanor was the first white child born in Chicago.
m. 21 DEC 1857 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, William Washington Gordon, b. 1834 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia, d. 11 SEP 1912 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM graduated from Yale University and was a cotton merchant in Savannah, Georgia. He was a Lieutenant in the Confederate Army during the Civil War. He lost everything in the war. After the war he served in the Georgia State Cavalry. He was appointed Brigadier General in 1898 in the Spanish American War, and was Commissioner to supervise the evacuation of the Spanish from Puerto Rico.
6 children: Eleanor Kinzie "Nell", Juliette Magill Kinzie "Daisy", Sarah Alice "Alice", Willaim Washington, Mabel Mclane, George Arthur "Arthur".
(10) Eleanor Kinzie "Nell" Gordon10 (Eleanor Lytle "Nellie" Kinzie9, Juliette Augusta Magill8, Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 SEP 1858 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 1933 .
(10) Juliette Magill Kinzie "Daisy" Gordon10 (Eleanor Lytle "Nellie" Kinzie9, Juliette Augusta Magill8, Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 31 OCT 1860 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia, d. 17 JAN 1927 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia.
NotesJULIETTE married a wealthy Englishman and moved to England. Her husband's infidelity became a public scandall when he left all his money to his mistress. After his death she returned to Savannah where she organized the first troop of Girl Guides on 9 March 1912. The name was changed to Girl Scouts in 1913. The inspiration came from her friendship in England with Sir Robert Baden Powell, founder of the Boy Scouts. Juliette was President of the Girl Scouts for several years. She was an amateur sculptor.
(10) Sarah Alice "Alice" Gordon10 (Eleanor Lytle "Nellie" Kinzie9, Juliette Augusta Magill8, Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1863 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia, d. DEC 1880 .
(10) Willaim Washington Gordon10 (Eleanor Lytle "Nellie" Kinzie9, Juliette Augusta Magill8, Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1866 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia, d. 1932 .
NotesWILLIAM graduated from Yale University. He was a lawyer at Savannah, Georgia, and a Major in the Georgia militia.
(10) Mabel Mclane Gordon10 (Eleanor Lytle "Nellie" Kinzie9, Juliette Augusta Magill8, Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1870 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia, d. ABT 1940 .

(8) Henry Wolcott Magill8 (Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 11 NOV 1815 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1818 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
(8) Alexander Wolcot Magill8 (Frances Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 16 OCT 1817 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. JUL 1867 Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.

(7) Henry Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 MAR 1788 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 5 APR 1846 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesHENRY was a physician. He was a Justice of the Peace and was appointed Collector of the Port at Middleton in 1828. In 1833, he moved to Chicago, Illinois, where he practiced medicine. Henry Wolcott had a private boarding house at Wolcott and Kinzie Streets in Chicago, in 1839.
m. 6 NOV 1813 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Mary Almira Starr, b. 2 MAR 1795 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 30 MAR 1870 .
9 children: Alexander, Henry Huntington, Caroline Starr, Edward, Frances Burbank, Ellen, Almira, Emma, Juliette.
(8) Alexander Wolcott8 (Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 OCT 1814 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 11 AUG 1884 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALEXANDER may have been the Alex Walcott, age 35, who was an engineer at Yuba City, California, in 1850. He was Cook County Surveyor in 1868. He was a surveyor at Chicago, Ilinois, in 1880.
m. 25 DEC 1845 , Dupage Co., Illinois, Mary A. Spaulding, b. 1817 ,, Massachusetts, d. 28 AUG 1909 , Cook Co., Illinois.
3 children: Henry Alexander, Charles, Cecilia.
(9) Henry Alexander Wolcott9 (Alexander Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1862 Chicago Heights, Cook Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesHENRY A. Wolcott of Illinois was a student at Notre Dame University in 1895-6. He married Mary Darrow.
m. 1 MAY 1882 , Cook Co., Illinois, Mary Elizabeth Darrow, b. 13 DEC 1861 Lowell, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 9 MAR 1926 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
1 children: Henry Alexander.
(10) Henry Alexander Wolcott10 (Henry Alexander Wolcott9, Alexander Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 SEP 1882 ,, Illinois, d. .
Notes1918 Draft Registration:
Henry Alexander Wolcott 36, b. 2 Sep 1882 Chicago, Cook, Illinois, Second hand? mach., Moor Bros., New York Life Bldg., wife Grace, medium height and build, dark eyes, dark hair.

1930 Chicago IL:
Henry A Wolcott 36, b. IL, broker, railroad machinery
Grace A Wolcott 26, b. NY
William H Wolcott 3 8/12, b. IL
(9) Charles Wolcott9 (Alexander Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1864 ,, Illinois, d. .
(9) Cecilia Wolcott9 (Alexander Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1865 ,, Illinois, d. .
(8) Henry Huntington Wolcott8 (Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 AUG 1816 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 28 SEP 1890 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
NotesHENRYmoved to Chicago in 1832 with his brother, Alexander. They lived with the family of his cousin, Mrs. John Kinzie. Henry Huntington Wolcott of Racine Co., Wisconsin, purchased 160 acres of government land at Racine Co. in 1843. He was listed as H. H. Wolcott in the 1844 city directory of Chicago, as clerk at Humphries & Winslow's, and residing at the City Hotel, and/or the Henry Wolcott, clerk at the post office and resident at the City Hotel. He was later in the transportation business on the Great Lakes and the Illinois and Michigan Canal. In 1859 returned to the East where he and his childhood friend, Eben Townsend Starr, and others formed the Starr Arms Company at Lowell, Massachusetts. Henry was a major investor and President of the company, which moved to Binghampton, and finally to Yonkers, New York. Henry and Eben Townsend grew up together at Middletown, Connecticut, and shared a great-grandfather, Jehosaphat Starr. They established an armory at Yonkers, New York. Henry held several patents for inventions connected with guns. Their company manufactured arms for the Union Army during the Civil War. In 1860 it accepted a contract for 12,000 pistols, then another 8,000 and 10,000 breech loading carbines.They had armories at Binghampton and Yonkers. After the war, they sold surplus arms to foreign governments. In 1880 Henry was a paper box manufacturer in New York City. Henry's son, Townsend, was named after Eben Starr and was the Executor of Eben's estate in 1899. His obituary said he was survived by his wife, two sons, and a daughter. Research on Henry and Eben Starr is being done by Robin Eichleay, P. O. Box 49297, Los Angeles CA 90049, 612 860-2783
m. 13 OCT 1852 Niagara Falls, Niagara Co., New York, Elizabeth Franklin Townsend, b. 21 NOV 1820 Goshen, Orange Co., New York, d. 10 JUL 1896 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
5 children: Elizabeth Mary, Henry, Townsend, Jennie, Juliette.
(9) Elizabeth Mary Wolcott9 (Henry Huntington Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1854 ,, New York, d. 1941 .
(9) Henry Wolcott9 (Henry Huntington Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 OCT 1855 ,, New York, d. 21 JUL 1938 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesHENRY was a merchant in New York City in 1880. In 1932, he donated a memorial window to the Tolland, England, church. The Wolcott Memorial Chapel in St. Paul's Church, Brookline, Massachusetts, was given by his widow in memory of Henry and Elizabeth Wolcott and their descendants, Henry Huntington Wolcott and his wife, Elizabeth Townsend, and their sons, Henry and Huntington, and their daughter, Elizabeth, in 1944. Henry was Rhode Island state vice president of the Wolcott Society before his marriage.
m. 6 FEB 1929 Brookline, Norfolk Co., Massachusetts, Cora Codman, b. 12 JUL 1874 , d. Brookline, Norfolk Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesCORA was the author of "The Codmans of Charlestown and Boston, 1637-1929".
(9) Townsend Wolcott9 (Henry Huntington Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1857 ,, New York, d. 29 APR 1910 New York City, New York.
NotesTOWNSEND was a member and officer of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. He was one of the authors of "The Electro Magnet", published in 1900. He was Secretary-Treasurer of the Wolcott Society. He created a card index of Wolcott Society members, for which the Society paid him $7 in 1909.
(9) Jennie Wolcott9 (Henry Huntington Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1859 , d. 1863 .
(9) Juliette Wolcott9 (Henry Huntington Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1863 , d. 1864 .
(8) Caroline Starr Wolcott8 (Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 8 OCT 1818 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1901 .
m. 19 JUN 1837 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Joseph Neree Balestier, b. 1 APR 1814 Martinique, West Indies, d. 1888 Arlington, Bennington Co., Vermont.
Spouse NotesJOSEPH was schooled by his brother's sister-in-law, Harriet Revere, daughter of Paul Revere. He then studied law. In 1835 he moved to Chicago where he practiced law for 7 years. He was a delegate to the convention that nominated Abraham Lincoln for President. In 1842 the Balestiers moved to New York City, where he was senior partner in the law firm, Balestier & Lane. He retired to his home, "Beechwood, in Vermont, where he died.
5 children: Robert Starr, Henry Wolcott, John Augustus, Joseph Neree, Caroline Wolcott.
(9) Robert Starr Balestier9 (Caroline Starr Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 OCT 1838 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 23 NOV 1903 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York.
m. 1865 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York, Mary Holmes , b. 1843 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York, d. 15 JAN 1867 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York.
(9) Robert Starr Balestier9 (Caroline Starr Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 OCT 1838 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 23 NOV 1903 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York.
m. 1868 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York, Fannie Maria , b. 27 APR 1837 Holmesville, Otsego Co., New York, d. 26 AUG 1915 Los Angeles, Los Angeles Co., California.
Spouse NotesFANNIE was Joseph's sister-in-law, sister of his first wife.
4 children: Robert Joseph, Mary C., Henry W., Emma.
(10) Robert Joseph Balestier10 (Robert Starr Balestier9, Caroline Starr Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 JAN 1869 Brattleboro, Windham Co., Vermont, d. 5 MAR 1947 Susquehanna, Susquehanna Co., Pennsylvania.
(10) Mary C. Balestier10 (Robert Starr Balestier9, Caroline Starr Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .

(9) Henry Wolcott Balestier9 (Caroline Starr Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1840 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 23 AUG 1870 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesHENRY was a lawyer and an insurance agent in New York City,
m. 1860 Anna Smith, b. 1838 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. 22 MAR 1919 Brattleboro, Windham Co., Vermont.
4 children: Caroline Starr, Charles Wolcott "Wolcott", Beatty S., Josephine.
(10) Caroline Starr Balestier10 (Henry Wolcott Balestier9, Caroline Starr Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 31 DEC 1865 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. 19 DEC 1939 , Sussex, England.
NotesCAROLYN and her mother came to London in 1889 to care for her sick brother. She married Rudyard Kiplink there, and the couple settled on her parents property in Brattleboro, Vermont. After a family quarrel, they returned to England.
(10) Charles Wolcott "Wolcott" Balestier10 (Henry Wolcott Balestier9, Caroline Starr Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 DEC 1861 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. 5 DEC 1891 Dresden, Saxony, Germany.
NotesCHARLES was raised by his grandfather Smith. He attended Cornell University and gave his attention to journalism. He edited an unsuccessful illustrated newspaper in New York called "Time", and wrote short stories for New York newspapers. He was author of "James G. Blaine; A Sketch of His Life" published in 1884. He left New York to become managing editor of the London Tid Bits in 1888 as a agent for an American publisher. He joined with William Heinemann and became managing editor of Heineman and Balestier, publishers of the "English Library", American and English books sold on the continent. He also wrote a number of books which met with success. He was a close friend of James McNeil Whistler and Rudyard Kipling. He served as an agent for Kipling, who had great affection for him and married his sister very shortly after Charles died. He died in Germany of Typhoid.
(10) Beatty S. Balestier10 (Henry Wolcott Balestier9, Caroline Starr Wolcott8, Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. 1936 .
NotesBEATTY died in poverty.

(8) Emma Wolcott8 (Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 26 JUL 1832 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. AUG 1848 .
(8) Juliette Wolcott8 (Henry Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 NOV 1835 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 8 AUG 1836 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
(7) Alexander Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 14 FEB 1790 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 NOV 1830 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1807. He subsequently studied medicine with Dr. Nathan Smith at Hanover, New Hampshire. He enlisted 25 May 1812 and was commissioned Surgeon's Mate in the U.S. Army, stationed at Ft. Moultrie, South Carolina, and Governors Island. After the war he established himself as a physician at Vincennes, Indiana. Alexander was appointed Indian Agent at Detroit in 1819, and accompanied Gov. Lewis Cass on his exploration of Lake Superior and the Mississippi headwaters in 1820. He was appointed Indian Agent at Chicago in 1820. His residence in Chicago was call "Cobweb Castle", and he lived there until his marriage in 1823. It was the first wedding in Chicago. He was also a Justice of the Peace. In 1830 he purchased for 600 dollars 8 lots in Chicago. His land is now the site of the Marina City Towers complex. His widow inherited his property and deeded these lands to David Hunter. On the 1830 census he is recorded at Fort Dearborn as a family with Alexander 40-50, 1 male 20-30, 1 male 10-15, 1 male 5-10, and 5 females age 60-70, Eleanor 30-40, 20-30, 15-20, 10-15, and 5-10, the elder woman probably his mother-in-law. His will left his property to his wife and his daughter, Mary Ann, his only living child.
m. 20 JUL 1823 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Eleanor Marion Kinzie, b. DEC 1804 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 1 AUG 1849 Detroit, Wayne Co., Michigan.
Spouse NotesELEANOR was the first white child born in Chicago, Illinois.
3 children: Mary Ann, Ellen Maria, Alexander.
(8) Mary Ann Wolcott8 (Alexander Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1825 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 16 JAN 1832 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
(8) Ellen Maria Wolcott8 (Alexander Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1826 ,, Illinois, d. CHILD .
(8) Alexander Wolcott8 (Alexander Wolcott7, Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1829 ,, Illinois, d. CHILD .
(7) Mary Ann Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 11 FEB 1792 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 SEP 1865 .
(6) Alexander Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 SEP 1758 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 JUN 1828 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1778 and practiced law in Windsor, where he was a Representative to the General Assembly for five sessions, 1796-1801. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. He had warrant of 50,000 acres on south side of Powell's Muntain on Guest's River, and 100,000 acres on the west bank of Tottery Creek in 1795. In 1796 he sold a grant of 100,000 acres on the East Branch of the Big Sandy River in Russell Co., Virginia, to Ebenezer Fitch Bissell. In 1799 he held 12,500 acres of land in Grayson Co., Virginia. His land holding claims were disputed due to disagreements between Virginia and Kentucky over their borders, and "Wolcotters" became a term for people with dubious land claims. Alexander Smyth of Wythe Co., Virginia, contracted with Alexander Wolcott of Connecticut to survey 850,000 acres of land. An 1800 deed conveyed 1,034 acres of land from Alexander Smyth to Alexander Wolcott of Windsor, Connecticut, for 434 dollars. Alexander was at Middleton, Connecticut in 1800, were he was a Justice of the Peace. He was Collector of Customs for Middletown there from 1801 until his death in 1828, when he was succeeded by his eldest son. He was one of the early manufacturers of woolen cloth in this country. Alexander was one of the leaders of the Republican Party of Connecticut. He was nominated for the U.S. Supreme Court by President Madison in 1810, but the nomination failed to get the approval of the Senate for political reasons, 24 to 9. It was said "But he was widely unpopular as revenue collectors tend to be". He was a member of the State Constitutional Convention in 1818.
m. 7 JUN 1807 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Lucy Waldo, b. 10 AUG 1766 Falmouth, Cumberland Co., Maine, d. 10 SEP 1839 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
(6) Guy Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 AUG 1760 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 SEP 1823 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
NotesGUY was at Litchfield Co., Connecticut in 1790, with a family of 2 males under 16, 2 males over 16, and 2 females. He settled at Torrington, Connecticut, in 1783, on a farm a mile and a half west of what became Wolcottville. The name was given the town by popular vote after Guy and Frederick Wolcott built a woolen mill on the Waterbury River there in 1813. Guy was elected deacon of the Torrington church in 1821. The mill ran into financial difficulties, and in 1822 Guy moved to Tallmadge, Ohio, where his eldest son had settled a few years earlier. Tallmadge was in Portage County until 1840 when Summit County was created. Guy and his wife, Abigail, were 3rd cousins.
m. 5 OCT 1781 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Abigail Allyn, b. 5 OCT 1765 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 21 FEB 1836 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
13 children: , Abigail, Abigail, Guy, James, Elizur "Eli", Frederick, Anna, Almira, Amanda, Eleanor, George, Allyn Ellsworth.
(7) Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 12 FEB 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Abigail Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 FEB 1784 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 1784 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(7) Abigail Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 JUL 1785 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 3 AUG 1830 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
m. 26 MAY 1803 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Nathan Gillett, b. 7 MAR 1781 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesNATHAN Gillett Jr. becamea freeman of Torrington CT in 1802. Moved to Western Reserve 1817.
10 children: Eliza M., Catharine Wolcott, Charlotte, Lucretia, Alexander Wolcott, Mary Ann, Amanda, Abigail "Abby", Annis, Oliver Wolcott.
(8) Eliza M. Gillett8 (Abigail Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1804 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 12 SEP 1846 .
m. 15 OCT 1820 Titus Chapman, b. 23 APR 1793 , Rutland Co., Vermont, d. 30 JUN 1866 .
Spouse NotesTITUS' family moved to Trumbull Co., Ohio, in 1806. The area became Summit Co. He served in the War of 1812. He was a farmer at Tallmadge Township, Ohio, in 1850, with wife Sophia. The Chapman family, or the descendants of Robert Chapman, one of the first settlers of Say-Brook, Conn., with genealogical notes of William Chapman, who settled in New London, Conn.; Edward Chapman, who settled at Windsor, Conn.; John Chapman, of Stonington, Conn.; and Rev. Benjamin Chapman, of Southington, Conn., by F. W. Chapman (Hartford: Case, Tiffany and Co., 1854), p. 217, 242-243
2 children: Keziah, George.
(9) Keziah Chapman9 (Eliza M. Gillett8, Abigail Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 4 JUL 1824 Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1915 Franklin, Franklin Co., Nebraska.
NotesThe Chapman family, or the descendants of Robert Chapman, one of the first settlers of Say-Brook, Conn., with genealogical notes of William Chapman, who settled in New London, Conn.; Edward Chapman, who settled at Windsor, Conn.; John Chapman, of Stonington, Conn.; and Rev. Benjamin Chapman, of Southington, Conn., by F. W. Chapman (Hartford: Case, Tiffany and Co., 1854), p. 243, 254

(10) Henry Liberty Bates10 (Keziah Chapman9, Eliza M. Gillett8, Abigail Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 JAN 1853 Harmar, Washington Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesHENRY was at Oberlin, Ohio, in 1880, and at North Forest Grove, Oregon, in 1900. He was Dean of the faculty at Pacific University.
(10) Charles Otis Bates10 (Keziah Chapman9, Eliza M. Gillett8, Abigail Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 31 MAY 1855 Almont, Lapeer Co., Michigan, d. 25 NOV 1947 Zenith, King Co., Washington.
NotesCHARLES was editor and manager of the Beatrice Express newspaper. He studied law and was admitted to the Nebraska bar in 1878, being elected Prosocuting Attorney in 1905. . He joined the Nebraska National Guard as a private in 1880 and rose through the ranks to Major

(9) Mary E. L. Whitter9 (Lucretia Gillett8, Abigail Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 OCT 1853 , d. .
m. 2 JUN 1871 Simpson Wesley Horner, b. 1847 ,, Pennsylvania, d. 7 MAR 1913 Farmington, Oakland Co., Michigan.
Spouse NotesSIMPSON was a Methodist minister at Brownsville, Pennsylvania, 1868-70, at Connellsville, Pensylvania, 1870-1, and at Baraboo, Wisconsin, 1877-80. He was pastor of the Methodist Church at Bay City, Michigan, in 1897. His father was born in England and his mother in Pennsylvania.
2 children: Elizabeth, Caroline Goss "Carrie".

(8) Alexander Wolcott Gillett8 (Abigail Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 19 MAY 1812 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1814 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.

(8) Oliver Wolcott Gillett8 (Abigail Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 MAY 1823 , d. .
(7) Guy Wolcott7 (Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 OCT 1787 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1865 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesGUY bought one-eighth interest in the Wilsons Sawmill Company in 1811. In 1817 he moved from Wolcottville, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, to Portage County, Ohio, where he bought a large farm in Tallmadge Township. Tallmadge became part of Summit County in 1840, but part of it is still in Portage County.
m. 24 APR 1821 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Annis "Annie" Porter, b. 12 NOV 1801 Waterbury, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 2 FEB 1882 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesANNIS' family moved to Talmadge, Ohio, in 1817. She lived with her daughter, Charlotte, in 1880.
8 children: James Orin, Elizabeth Elvira, Charlotte Amanda, Lemuel Porter, Elizur V., Eleanor, Franklin Maginnis "Frank", Ellen Coe.
(8) James Orin Wolcott8 (Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 APR 1823 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 29 DEC 1876 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesJames inherited his father's homestead and half of the farm at Tallmadge. The other half of the farm went to his brother, Lemuel. He was at Tallmadge in 1860, with Ellen, Elizabeth, Jane, Judson, and Waldo Wolcott.
m. 4 NOV 1846 Jane E. Lewis, b. 27 JUN 1826 Portland, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 8 FEB 1850 Northampton, Summit Co., Ohio.
2 children: Elizabeth Elvira, Jane Elizabeth "Jennie",
(9) Elizabeth Elvira Wolcott9 (James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 JUL 1848 Northampton, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1920 .
NotesELIZABETH was a member of the Wolcott Society in 1914-19 residing at Tallmadge, Ohio.
(9) Jane Elizabeth "Jennie" Wolcott9 (James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 FEB 1850 Northampton, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 8 AUG 1918 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
m. 1881 Detroit, Wayne Co., Michigan, Lemuel P. Porter, b. 1840 ,, Ohio, d. 15 MAR 1895 Saginaw, Saginaw Co., Michigan.
Spouse NotesLEMUEL was an architect. He was comillioned as 1st Lieutenant in the 1st Regt., Ohio Lt. Arty. in 1861.
(9) Jane Elizabeth "Jennie" Wolcott9 (James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 FEB 1850 Northampton, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 8 AUG 1918 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
m. 6 DEC 1895 Ames, Story Co., Iowa, John Joseph Wiltse, b. 30 JUN 1841 Catskill, Greene Co., New York, d. 1915 Des Moines, Polk Co., Iowa.
Spouse NotesJOHN's family moved to Iowa about 1855 and settled near Ames, Iowa. He enlisted in the 23rd Iowa Inf. Regt. in 1862 and served for four years. He moved from Ames to Des Moines in 1896.
(8) James Orin Wolcott8 (Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 APR 1823 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 29 DEC 1876 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesJames inherited his father's homestead and half of the farm at Tallmadge. The other half of the farm went to his brother, Lemuel. He was at Tallmadge in 1860, with Ellen, Elizabeth, Jane, Judson, and Waldo Wolcott.
m. 26 JUN 1850 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Ellen A. Lewis, b. 16 AUG 1831 Portland, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 6 JAN 1921 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesELLEN came with her parents to Northampton, Ohio, when she was 7. In 1880 she was at Tallmadge, Ohio, with Elizabeth E., Jennie E., Waldo W., and Mary E. Wolcott. Lemuel P. Porter who later married her daughter, was living with the family. Ellen was active in the Congregational church.
3 children: Judson Eugene, Waldo Welton, Mary Ella.
(9) Judson Eugene Wolcott9 (James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 MAY 1852 Northampton, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 4 JAN 1942 Cleveland Heights, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesJUDSON moved to Cleveland, Ohio, in 1876, and was living there in 1900, age 48, with Sarah M. 46, Harry W. 21, James M. 19, Robinson B. 10, and Judson E. Jr. 7, all born Ohio, except Harry who was born in West Virginia. Judson was a salesman for the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company. He worked for the Hartford Insurance Company for 40 years, first at Akron, then for a dozen years at Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and finally at Cleveland, Ohio. Judson attended the first Wolcott reunion in 1905, of which he said in 1923: "Eighteen years ago we received a notice of the Wolcott meeting to be held at Orwell, September 23, 1905. Mrs. Wolcott and myself went down. Teams were at the station to carry us three miles out to the beautiful lawn and trees of the home of Sereno Wolcott, who is here with us, as is N. A. Wolcott and Warren Wolcott." He was elected first President of the Society of Descendants of Henry Wolcott in 1906 and gave a speech at that reunion, and Society vice-president for Ohio in 1909, residing at East Cleveland. He was First Vice-President 1914-5, and President of the Society in 1920 and 1921. He attended most reunions until his death and was considered one of the most active members of the Society. He attended all but two reunions up to 1941. In 1980 he lived at 15904 Detroit Ave., Lakewood, and he died at home of his son, James, at 12690 Cedar Rd., Cleveland Heights.
m. 24 AUG 1876 Sarah Matilda Robeson, b. 15 FEB 1854 Loudonville, Holmes Co., Ohio, d. 3 OCT 1929 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
5 children: Claude Leon Van Buren, Harry Ward Emerson, James Victor, Robeson Brainard, Judson Eugene.
(10) Claude Leon Van Buren Wolcott10 (Judson Eugene Wolcott9, James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 SEP 1877 Preston, Preston Co., West Virginia, d. Detroit, Wayne Co., Michigan.
NotesClaude Leon Van Buren Wolcott
Birth Date: 22 Sep 1877
Birth Place: Preston, West Virginia
Birth County: Preston
Gender: Male
Father's Name: Judson Eugene Wolcott
Mother's name: Sarah Matilda Robinson

CLAUDE attended the 1912 Wolcott Society reunion with his father.

1918 Draft Registration:
Claude Leon Wolcott 40, b. 22 Sep 1877 Cleveland, Cuyahoga, Ohio, salesman, relative Mr. J.E. Wolcott, short, stout, blue eyes, dark hair.

Notes

Name Age
Harry W Wolcott 41, b. WV, commercial traveller, Wholesale Mfg. lamps
Pearle Wolcott 40, b. Oh
Arlene Wolcott 14, b. OH
(10) James Victor Wolcott10 (Judson Eugene Wolcott9, James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 26 AUG 1881 ,, Ohio, d. MAR 1952 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesJAMES attended Western Reserve University 1901-2, and graduated from Western Reserve University Law School in 1905. He practiced law at Cleveland, Ohio. In 1930 he was at Shaker Heights, Ohio, with Elnora F., Virginia L., Roger V., and Jeanne M. Wolcott.

1918 Draft Registration:
James Victor Wolcott 37, b. 26 Aug 1881 , Cleveland Heights, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, moving picture show, self, Cleveland, wife Elnora Wolcott, Cleveland Heights, medium height, slender, blue eyes, L.B. hair
(10) Robeson Brainard Wolcott10 (Judson Eugene Wolcott9, James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 APR 1890 ,, Ohio, d. 3 DEC 1934 Lakewood, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesROBESON attended the 1912 Wolcott Society reunion with his father. He enlisted in 1918 and trained at Camp Greenleaf, Georgia. He served as a Sergeant in the Medical Corps. He was sent overseas with the 108th Base Hospital . In 1919 he was at Nantes, France. He invented a fuse plug and an attachment plug for electrical appliances. His electric lampsocket was patented in 1919 with Herbert W. Wolcott as witness, possibly his brother, Harry.
(10) Judson Eugene Wolcott10 (Judson Eugene Wolcott9, James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 DEC 1892 Wilkinsburg, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, d. 23 OCT 1938 Lakewood, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesJUDSON was a mess sergeant at Camp Dix, New Jersey, and went to France with the 34th Inf. Regt. He returned to America July 1918. He was a salesman for the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection & Insurance Co. He joined the Wolcott Society in 1934 as member 193, residing at Cleveland, Ohio.
(9) Waldo Welton Wolcott9 (James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 NOV 1858 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 21 AUG 1926 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesWALDO was a voter at Tallmadge, Ohio, in 1880. Waldo W. Wolcott purchased 160 acres of government land at Tillamook Co., Oregon, in 1890. He purchased another 160 acres at Washington Co., Oregon, in 1892.
m. 16 MAR 1882 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Ida Belle Limbert, b. 19 JAN 1857 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 17 AUG 1919 Des Moines, Polk Co., Iowa.
2 children: Nina Brainerd, Hilda Belle.
(10) Nina Brainerd Wolcott10 (Waldo Welton Wolcott9, James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 MAY 1883 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 24 MAR 1964 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
(10) Hilda Belle Wolcott10 (Waldo Welton Wolcott9, James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 26 OCT 1889 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 14 MAY 1985 St. Cloud, Osceola Co., Florida.
NotesHILDA joined the Wolcott Society in 1964 as member #710, residing at St. Cloud, Florida.
(9) Mary Ella Wolcott9 (James Orin Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 DEC 1860 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. OCT 1925 .
(8) Elizabeth Elvira Wolcott8 (Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 25 MAY 1824 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 14 MAY 1845 South Hadley, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts.
NotesEMILY died at Mt. Holyoke Seminary at age 21. She was in her last year in the seminary.
(8) Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8 (Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 3 SEP 1827 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 19 MAY 1891 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
m. 12 OCT 1851 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Dennis Edson Fenn, b. 16 MAR 1828 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 8 MAY 1901 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesDennis was a dentist and farmer at Tallmadge. In 1852, he purchased a 215 acre farm where he lived the rest of his life. In 1861, he began the study of dentistry and opened an office at Tallmadge. He was a member of the Tallmadge Congregational Church.
4 children: Wilbur Wolcott, Annis Emeline, Ellen Mable, Harriet Woodruff.
(9) Wilbur Wolcott Fenn9 (Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 19 AUG 1852 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 3 MAR 1905 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesWILBUR was in business with his father at Tallmadge, Ohio.
m. 8 NOV 1882 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Eliza Ellen Miller, b. 6 SEP 1861 Quincy, Adams Co., Illinois, d. 7 DEC 1937 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
10 children: Ellen Coe Wolcott, , Alfred Miller, Daniel Edson, Clara Edith, Marshall Wolcott, Doris Miller, Howard Wolcott, Marjorie Annis, Wilber Wolcott.
(10) Ellen Coe Wolcott Fenn10 (Wilbur Wolcott Fenn9, Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 APR 1884 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 9 FEB 1977 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.

Notesposthumous child, originally named Wilbur W. Fenn for his father; legally changed name to Todd W. Fenn
(9) Annis Emeline Fenn9 (Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 JAN 1855 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 26 SEP 1937 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesEMELINE's name is also given as Annis Emeline, but her descendant Linda Alexander said that the family had it recorded as Emeline Annis.
m. 18 APR 1888 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, William Walker Carter, b. 29 SEP 1853 Brimfield, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 5 MAY 1940 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
3 children: Julia Annis, Charlotte Wolcott, H. Leone.
(10) Julia Annis Carter10 (Annis Emeline Fenn9, Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 OCT 1889 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 6 OCT 1969 .
(10) Charlotte Wolcott Carter10 (Annis Emeline Fenn9, Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 29 OCT 1890 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 14 AUG 1970 Cuyahoga Falls, Summit Co., Ohio.
(10) H. Leone Carter10 (Annis Emeline Fenn9, Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 DEC 1893 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 17 JUL 1971 Bradenton, Manatee Co., Florida.
(9) Ellen Mable Fenn9 (Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 JAN 1871 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 5 JAN 1871 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
(9) Harriet Woodruff Fenn9 (Charlotte Amanda Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 MAY 1873 La Cygne, Linn Co., Kansas, d. APR 1907 .
m. 6 MAR 1895 Alvin Herrick, b. , d. .
(8) Lemuel Porter Wolcott8 (Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 18 AUG 1831 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 10 NOV 1876 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesLEMUEL was a life-long farmer in Tallmadge, Ohio. His father split the family farm between Lemuel and his brother, James. James retained the original homestead while Lemuel built a new house in 1856 which remained in the Wolcott family for five generations. Lemuel and James attended the nation's Centennial celebration in Philadelphia in 1876, caught a disease there and both came home to die later that year. The following sketch appears in History of Summit County, by William Henry Perrin, printed in 1881): "Harriet E. Treat, farmer; P. O. Tallmadge; is the widow of Lemuel P. Walcott, who was born in Tallmadge Aug. 18, 1831; his childhood was passed on the farm, where he remained until he had grown to manhood; he obtained his education in the common schools, the Windom Academy and the Nelson High School; after completing his education, he returned to the farm, and there lived until it was divided between himself and brothers. In November, 1856, he married Harriet E., daughter of Richard and Amoret Treat, who shared his happiness until death separated them; he died Nov. 10, 1876, at the age of 45 years; he was a man much missed in the surrounding community in which he lived, for his amiable disposition, gentlemanly bearing and devotion to his church....".
m. 2 NOV 1856 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, Harriet Esther Treat, b. 9 SEP 1831 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 5 SEP 1921 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesThe Treat Family: A genealogy of Trott, Tratt, and Treat for fifteen generations, and four hundred and fifty years in England and America ..., by John Harvey Treat (Salem, MA: Salem Press, 1893), p. 387, 457
3 children: Mary Elizabeth, Flora Isabel, Bryan Treat.
(9) Mary Elizabeth Wolcott9 (Lemuel Porter Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 JUL 1859 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. Omaha, Douglas Co., Nebraska.
NotesMARY E. Wolcott of Omaha, Nebraska, was a member of the Wolcott Society 1914-15, and may be the Mary E. Wolcott who was a member in 1916 residing at Prarie, Colorado.
m. 11 APR 1888 Henry Bryan Treat, b. 4 OCT 1856 Bryan, Williams Co., Ohio, d. 10 DEC 1917 Washington, District of Columbia.
Spouse NotesHENRY worked for the wholesale hardware dealer, Wright & Wilhelmy. He was a member of the Executive Committee of the Royal Highlanders Society for many years.
2 children: Howard Wolcott, Helen Fulton.
(10) Howard Wolcott Treat10 (Mary Elizabeth Wolcott9, Lemuel Porter Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 MAY 1889 Fremont, Dodge Co., Nebraska, d. .
NotesHOWARD was in the Baloon Department of the Signal Corps, and was stationed at Washington, D. C. in 1918.
(10) Helen Fulton Treat10 (Mary Elizabeth Wolcott9, Lemuel Porter Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 DEC 1890 Fremont, Dodge Co., Nebraska, d. .
(9) Flora Isabel Wolcott9 (Lemuel Porter Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 FEB 1864 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 21 AUG 1942 Oberlin, Lorain Co., Ohio.
NotesFLORA graduated from Oberline College, Ohio in 1884. After teaching there for a few years, she became the Assistant Registrar in 1891, and Registrar in 1905. She retired from that position in 1929.
(9) Bryan Treat Wolcott9 (Lemuel Porter Wolcott8, Guy Wolcott7, Guy Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 18 OCT 1867 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 14 SEP 1923 Tallmadge, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesBRYAN was a life-long farmer in Tallmadge, Ohio. He lived on his father's farm.
