NotesFREDERICK graduated from the U. S. Naval Academy in 1913.
(10) Elsie Pierrepont Davis10 (Mary Ellen Taintor9, Delia Williams Ellsworth8, Sophia Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 NOV 1897 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 APR 1906 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(8) Ellsworth8 (Sophia Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1821 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1821 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(8) Ellen Sophia Ellsworth8 (Sophia Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 4 SEP 1823 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 29 JAN 1897 Rutland, Rutland Co., Vermont.
NotesELLEN was born Sophia and her given name was changed to Ellen in childhood.
m. 14 MAY 1845 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, George Washington Strong, b. 14 FEB 1818 Rutland, Rutland Co., Vermont, d. 28 OCT 1858 Rutland, Rutland Co., Vermont.
6 children: Catherine Ellsworth, , , , , .
(9) Catherine Ellsworth Strong9 (Ellen Sophia Ellsworth8, Sophia Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 26 JUL 1846 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .

(9) Strong9 (Ellen Sophia Ellsworth8, Sophia Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1854 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1854 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

NotesELLEN was born Sophia and her given name was changed to Ellen in childhood.
m. 2 AUG 1878 ,, Connecticut, John Prout, b. 21 NOV 1815 Salisbury, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 28 AUG 1890 Rutland, Rutland Co., Vermont.
Spouse NotesJOHN was a judge.
(8) Ellsworth8 (Sophia Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1825 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1825 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(8) Henry Martin Ellsworth8 (Sophia Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 29 APR 1827 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 21 OCT 1829 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Ursula Wolcott7 (Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 NOV 1788 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 JUN 1868 .
NotesURSULA lived at East Windsor, Connecticut, in 1840.
m. 10 MAY 1815 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Newton Skinner, b. 10 OCT 1782 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 MAR 1825 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesNEWTON graduated from Yale University in 1804. He was pastor of the New Britain Congregational Church. He lived at East Windsor, Connecticut, in 1840.
3 children: Mary Gay, Samuel Wolcott, Ann Grant.
(8) Mary Gay Skinner8 (Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 14 FEB 1818 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 OCT 1898 .
m. 6 OCT 1840 Aaron Russell Livermore, b. 6 OCT 1810 Mansfield, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. East Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesAARON attended Amhurst College 1833-1836, and Lane Theological Seminary in 1837. He graduated from the East Windsor Hill Theological Seminary in 1839. He was a clergyman at East Haven, Connecticut, in 1880, age 70, with wife, Mary G. 62, and daughter, Mary C. 29
3 children: Russell Wolcott, Charles Herbert, Mary H..
(9) Russell Wolcott Livermore9 (Mary Gay Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 FEB 1849 Mansfield, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. 21 APR 1914 Pates, Robeson Co., North Carolina.
NotesRUSSELL received a BA degreee from the Massachusetts Agricultural College in 1872 and graduated from the Yale School of Lawe in 1875. He was a lawyer at New Haven for 2 years and then moved to Toledo, Ohio, where he practiced law for 6 years. He then moved to North Carolina to assist his wife's brother, and settled at Pates where he was a cotton planter, merchant, and dealer in turpentine and naval supplies.
m. 5 MAY 1880 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, Elizabeth Taylor Hayes, b. , d. .
3 children: Mary Hoyland, Henry Wolcott, Russell Hayes.
(10) Mary Hoyland Livermore10 (Russell Wolcott Livermore9, Mary Gay Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 11 OCT 1883 , Robeson Co., North Carolina, d. 1 JAN 1965 Fayetteville, Cumberland Co., North Carolina.
NotesMARY was a social worker.
(10) Henry Wolcott Livermore10 (Russell Wolcott Livermore9, Mary Gay Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .
(10) Russell Hayes Livermore10 (Russell Wolcott Livermore9, Mary Gay Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .
(9) Charles Herbert Livermore9 (Mary Gay Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 OCT 1856 Mansfield, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. 20 OCT 1928 Monterey, Monterey Co., California.
NotesCHARLES received a BA degree from Yale in 1879; was teacher and principal of Guilford Institute, Guilford, Connecticut, 1879-1883. He received his PhD. from of Johns Hopkins University in 1886. He was a university fellow in history, 1884-1885; instructor in History and German at Hopkins Grammar School, New Haven, Connecticut, 1885-1886; instructor in History at the University of California, 1886-1888; Professor of History at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Boston, 1888-1893; Principal of Adelphia Academy, Brooklyn, New York, 1893-1896 and elected President of Adelphi College in 1896. He was the winner of $50,000 for the Bok Peace Prize in 1924.
m. Mettie Norton Tuttle, b. , d. .
2 children: George Kirchway, Henry Wolcott.
(10) George Kirchway Livermore10 (Charles Herbert Livermore9, Mary Gay Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 18 APR 1891 Brookline, Norfolk Co., Massachusetts, d. .
NotesGEORGE was a Lieutenant and an instructor at an Artillery school in France in 1918.
(10) Henry Wolcott Livermore10 (Charles Herbert Livermore9, Mary Gay Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .
NotesHENRY, of Hartford, Connecticut, served in Bttry. A, 135th Field Arty. Regt. in France in 1918.
(9) Mary H. Livermore9 (Mary Gay Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1851 ,, Connecticut, d. .
NotesMARY was a school teacher, living with her parents at East Haven, Connecticut, in 1880. She lived at Hartford, Connecticut, in 1918.
(8) Samuel Wolcott Skinner8 (Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 19 JUN 1820 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 16 AUG 1903 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesSAMUEL received a BA degree from Yale College in 1842 and a MA degree in 1846. He was liscenced as a medical doctor in 1846. He was Divison Surgeon with the 1st Connecticut Artillery at Arlington Virginia, from 1861 to 1865, during the Civil War. In 1866 he moved to Toledo, Ohio, where he had a medical practice. He served as the Toledo Health Officer and consulting surgeon for St. Vincent Hospital.
m. 16 SEP 1846 Dorianna Fuller, b. 18 OCT 1823 , d. 17 MAR 1919 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
5 children: Helen Wolcott, Alice Fuller, Edward Bissell, Roger Wolcott, Samuel Wolcott.
(9) Helen Wolcott Skinner9 (Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 SEP 1847 , d. 8 JUN 1935 .
m. 2 JUN 1875 Charles M. Dimmick, b. , d. .
(9) Alice Fuller Skinner9 (Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 FEB 1849 Windsor Locks, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 MAR 1919 .
m. 6 OCT 1868 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, John Hardy Doyle, b. 23 APR 1844 Mundy Creek, Perry Co., Ohio, d. 24 MAR 1919 Mundy Creek, Perry Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesJOHN attended Dennison University in Toledo, Ohio. He was admitted to the Ohio bar in 1864, and practiced law in Toledo, He was elected District Judge in 1879. In 1883 he was appointed to the Ohio Supreme Court, serving for one year.
6 children: Elizabeth Wolcott, Grace Alice, John Hardy, Frederick Ellsworth, Roger Wolcott, Helen Genevieve.
(10) Elizabeth Wolcott Doyle10 (Alice Fuller Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 AUG 1873 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. JUN 1939 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesELIZABETH joined the Wolcott Society as member 96 in 1930, residing at Innisfail, Toledo, Ohio.
(10) Grace Alice Doyle10 (Alice Fuller Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 NOV 1873 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 1933 .
NotesGRACE joined the Wolcott Society in 1925 as member #98, residing at Toledo,Ohio.
(10) John Hardy Doyle10 (Alice Fuller Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. INFANT Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
(10) Frederick Ellsworth Doyle10 (Alice Fuller Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. INFANT Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
(10) Roger Wolcott Doyle10 (Alice Fuller Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. INFANT Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
(10) Helen Genevieve Doyle10 (Alice Fuller Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 3 OCT 1886 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio, d. 6 JAN 1912 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
(9) Edward Bissell Skinner9 (Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 FEB 1852 , d. 1 MAY 1929 .
NotesEDWARD was a bookkeeper for MacLaren & Sprague.
m. 10 JAN 1877 Rose S. Jones, b. 13 MAR 1855 , d. 4 JUN 1933 .
4 children: Newton E., Helen E., Roger Wolcott, David Howe.
(10) Newton E. Skinner10 (Edward Bissell Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 4 JAN 1877 , d. .
(10) Helen E. Skinner10 (Edward Bissell Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 10 SEP 1880 , d. .

(10) David Howe Skinner10 (Edward Bissell Skinner9, Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 23 JUN 1892 , d. .
(9) Roger Wolcott Skinner9 (Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 16 MAY 1857 , d. 24 MAY 1857 .
(9) Samuel Wolcott Skinner9 (Samuel Wolcott Skinner8, Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 8 OCT 1861 , d. 25 SEP 1891 .
NotesSamuel was bookeeper for the Milburn Wagon Works at Toledo.
m. 10 JUN 1890 Lillian Bishop, b. , d. .
(8) Ann Grant Skinner8 (Ursula Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 23 AUG 1823 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 5 JUN 1893 .
m. 19 OCT 1848 East Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Sylvester Hine, b. , d. .
(7) Elizabeth Wolcott7 (Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 23 SEP 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 FEB 1873 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 23 NOV 1820 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Erastus Ellsworth, b. 20 JAN 1790 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 30 APR 1879 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesERASTUS was a merchant and an elder in the Presbyterian Church in New York City. He purchased a home at East Windsor from his brother-in-law, Elihu Wolcott. He was a founder of the Theological Institute of Connecticut.
5 children: Erastus Wolcott, Elizabeth, , Mary Lyman, Josiah Leavitt.
(8) Erastus Wolcott Ellsworth8 (Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 NOV 1822 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 5 JAN 1902 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesERASTUS graduated from Amhurst College in 1844 and studied law but was never admitted to the bar. He was a poet and an inventor. In 1845 he obtained a patent for a drawing or copying instrument, and for a device for making a siphon discharge at its highest point. One of his poems, "What is the Use", was published in "An American Anthology", by Edmund Steadman. Erastus engraved some of the pictures that appeared in "The Wolcott Memorial".
(8) Elizabeth Ellsworth8 (Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 APR 1824 New York City, New York, d. 7 DEC 1825 New York City, New York.
(8) Ellsworth8 (Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1826 New York City, New York, d. INFANT .
(8) Mary Lyman Ellsworth8 (Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1 NOV 1827 New York City, New York, d. .
m. 9 NOV 1848 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, William Wood, b. ABT 1823 Waterbury, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 9 AUG 1884 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM was a medical doctor. He was also an ornithologist, and the author of "The Birds of Connecticut".
2 children: Elizabeth Ellsworth, William Russell.
(9) Elizabeth Ellsworth Wood9 (Mary Lyman Ellsworth8, Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 31 AUG 1849 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. 9 NOV 1878 Lewis Sperry, b. 23 JAN 1848 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
2 children: Mary Elizabeth, Ellsworth.
(10) Mary Elizabeth Sperry10 (Elizabeth Ellsworth Wood9, Mary Lyman Ellsworth8, Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1 JAN 1880 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(10) Ellsworth Sperry10 (Elizabeth Ellsworth Wood9, Mary Lyman Ellsworth8, Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 JUN 1881 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(9) William Russell Wood9 (Mary Lyman Ellsworth8, Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 JUN 1859 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(8) Josiah Leavitt Ellsworth8 (Elizabeth Wolcott7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 25 MAY 1829 New York City, New York, d. 25 APR 1832 New York City, New York.
(7) Horace Wolcott7 (Jerusha Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 25 MAR 1794 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1838 , Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesHORACE was Captain of a cavalry unit at South Windsor. He moved first to Michigan, where he was a petitioner at Monroe Co. in 1831 and 1834, and later to Illinois, where he died. Horace Wolcott of Hartford Co., Connecticut purchased 279 acres of government land at Lenawee Co., Michigan, in 1825, where he was a fur trader. Horace Wolcott of Monroe Co., Michigan, purchased 3 acres of land at Wayne Co., Michigan, in 1825. An additional patent for 80 acres of land in Lenawee Co., issued in 1825, was confirmed in 1931. His brother, Elihu, was administrator of his estate.
(6) Arodi Wolcott6 (Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 29 SEP 1760 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 18 MAY 1805 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. DEC 1789 , Hartford Co., Connecticut, Ruth Pitkin, b. 1764 East Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 AUG 1811 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
4 children: Arodi Pitkin, Almira, , Mary.
(7) Arodi Pitkin Wolcott7 (Arodi Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 14 JUN 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 30 DEC 1842 .
(7) Almira Wolcott7 (Arodi Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 AUG 1793 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 FEB 1865 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesALMIRA's grave stone says she died 27 Feb. 1865, age 71. She and her sister, Mary, raised Julia, daughter of Simon and Betsy Loomis of South Windsor. Julia married Zenas Rider of Springfield, Massachusetts.
(7) Wolcott7 (Arodi Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 DEC 1795 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 DEC 1795 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Mary Wolcott7 (Arodi Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 APR 1797 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 MAR 1858 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. Russell Cone, b. , d. .
(6) Albert Wolcott6 (Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 19 DEC 1761 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesALBERT lived in the home built by his grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott, in 1704. He was at East Windsor, Connecticut in 1790, with a family of 1 male over 16, 1 male under 16, and 4 females. He was at Hartford Co. in 1810 with 1 male over 45 (Albert), 2 females 16-25 (Hannah & Cynthia), and 1 female 10-15 (Elizabeth). Following the death of his wife and only son, Albert and his four daughters, Cynthia, Hannah, Laura, and Elizabeth, moved to Cleveland, Ohio, in 1816. He brought with him the family Bible of his grandfather, Gov. Roger Wolcott, which was later deposited by his grandson, Stoughton Bliss, with the the Hartford, Connecticut, museum.
m. 26 APR 1786 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Hannah Loomis, b. 29 JUL 1765 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 JAN 1807 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
6 children: Hannah, Albert, Cynthia, Laura, Laura, Elizabeth "Betsey".
(7) Hannah Wolcott7 (Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 19 MAY 1786 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 10 MAY 1855 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
(7) Albert Wolcott7 (Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 NOV 1787 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 MAR 1810 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. Hannah Moore, b. ABT 1790 , d. ABT 1832 .
Spouse NotesHANNAH's grave stone says she died age 42; the date is unreadable.
(7) Cynthia Wolcott7 (Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 SEP 1789 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1848 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
m. 16 MAY 1813 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, William Bliss, b. 3 JAN 1790 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 SEP 1828 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM and his wife moved to Cleveland, Ohio, in 1815. He is considered the city's first silversmith. He also sold general goods and worked as a cabinet maker. He owned considerable property in Cleveland. They lived on Superior St., near West 3rd. Her father and sisters lived nearby. The Blisses were charter members of the Old Stone Church in Cleveland, Ohio. He died of malaria.
5 children: Albert Wolcott, Nancy Eliza, Louisa, Stoughton, William Samuel,
(8) Albert Wolcott Bliss8 (Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 8 MAR 1814 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 NOV 1849 Warren, Trumbull Co., Ohio.
m. 6 AUG 1846 Maria Harsh, b. , d. .
1 children: Albert Harsh.
(9) Albert Harsh Bliss9 (Albert Wolcott Bliss8, Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 JUL 1847 Warren, Trumbull Co., Ohio, d. 1 FEB 1852 .
(8) Nancy Eliza Bliss8 (Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 JAN 1817 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 17 SEP 1842 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
(8) Louisa Bliss8 (Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 JUN 1819 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. .
NotesLOUISA was born blind, and after her father's death was cared for by a cousin, Nancy Warner, Mrs. Proctor Pease, living in Michigan.
(8) Stoughton Bliss8 (Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 18 FEB 1823 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesSTOUGHTON remained unmarried after the death of his wife. He lived at the Kennard House hotel at Cleveland. He is said to have strongly resembled Oliver Wolcott, signer of the Declaration of Independence.
m. 1849 Maria Ann Sweet, b. 1826 Buffalo, Columbia Co., New York, d. 1850 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
(8) William Samuel Bliss8 (Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 MAY 1827 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 1881 Glenville, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesSAMUEL moved from Columbia, Tennessee, to Cleveland, Ohio, in 1872. In 1880 he was a newspaper publisher at Franklin, Indiana, but returned to Ohio where he died in 1881.
m. 17 DEC 1851 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, Lucy A. Gurley, b. , d. .
1 children: Lizzie.
(9) Lizzie Bliss9 (William Samuel Bliss8, Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 SEP 1852 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 28 NOV 1852 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
(8) William Samuel Bliss8 (Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 MAY 1827 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 1881 Glenville, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesSAMUEL moved from Columbia, Tennessee, to Cleveland, Ohio, in 1872. In 1880 he was a newspaper publisher at Franklin, Indiana, but returned to Ohio where he died in 1881.
m. 1865 Anna Maria Johnson, b. 1840 Stroupsville, Trumbull Co., Ohio, d. 1926 Berea, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
2 children: Harry Alfred, Maria Louise.
(9) Harry Alfred Bliss9 (William Samuel Bliss8, Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 3 AUG 1867 Columbia, Maury Co., Tennessee, d. 11 DEC 1937 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesHARRY was an amateur musician and played several instruments. He played at many affairs in the Cleveland area. He was President of the Bliss Supply Co. Mrs. Harry A. Bliss of Cleveland attended the 1914 Wolcott reunion, but the Blisses are not listed on the Society membership list until 1917. Harry was Ohio state vice president in 1918, and the 14th President of the Society of Descendants of Henry Wolcot, 1925-26.
m. 31 AUG 1910 L. Blanche "Blanche" Fisher, b. 11 AUG 1879 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 1953 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
2 children: Wolcott, Imogene Fisher.
(10) Wolcott Bliss10 (Harry Alfred Bliss9, William Samuel Bliss8, Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. INFANT .
(10) Imogene Fisher Bliss10 (Harry Alfred Bliss9, William Samuel Bliss8, Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 FEB 1918 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. 14 JAN 2003 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesIMOGENE attended Mt. Vernon Seminary and the Connecticut College for Women. She went to New York City in the 1960s where she was a Broadway and movie actress, appearing in THe King of Marvin Gardens, 1972 and Stone Pillow 1985, and in the Broadway shows The Women and Grease. She joined the Wolcott Society in 1918, residing at Cleveland, Ohio.
(9) Maria Louise Bliss9 (William Samuel Bliss8, Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 11 JUL 1871 Columbia, Maury Co., Tennessee, d. .
NotesMARIA lived at LaGrange, Illinois.
m. 28 MAR 1894 Wellington, Lorain Co., Ohio, Charles Phelps Horr, b. 20 JAN 1868 Lorain, Lorain Co., Ohio, d. 14 MAR 1936 La Grange, Cook Co., Illinois.
2 children: Cortland Bliss, Louise Bliss.
(10) Cortland Bliss Horr10 (Maria Louise Bliss9, William Samuel Bliss8, Cynthia Wolcott7, Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. La Grange, Cook Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesCORTLAND joined the Wolcott Society in 1920, residing at La Grange, Ohio.

(7) Laura Wolcott7 (Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 3 MAR 1793 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 20 SEP 1793 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Laura Wolcott7 (Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 NOV 1794 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 DEC 1795 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Elizabeth "Betsey" Wolcott7 (Albert Wolcott6, Erastus Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 OCT 1797 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
(5) Ursula Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 30 OCT 1724 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 5 APR 1788 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesURSULA was pictured in Ripley's "Believe It or Not" newspaper column because her father, brother, husband, son, and nephew were all Governors.
m. 10 NOV 1743 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Matthew Griswold, b. 25 MAR 1714 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 28 APR 1799 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesMATTHEW was a lawyer. He was a Representative to the General Assembly in 1759, and appointed Judge of the Superior Court in 1766. In 1769 he was elected Lieutenant Governor and Chief Justice of Connecticut. He served as Governor of Connecticut from 1784 until 1786, and was President of the state Convention for the adoption of the new Federal Constitution in 1788. He lived in the family home called Black Hall. Her eight daughter were sometimes known as "The Black Hall Boys".
8 children: Ursula, Hannah, Marian, John, Ursula, Matthew, Roger, Sally,
(6) Ursula Griswold6 (Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 18 NOV 1744 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 14 FEB 1745 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
(6) Hannah Griswold6 (Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 APR 1746 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 15 DEC 1755 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
(6) Marian Griswold6 (Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 APR 1750 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 17 JUN 1829 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
NotesMARIAN was considered a very beautiful, brilliant and outspoken woman. When Justin Ely, who became her 3rd husband, proposed marriage she replied, "Oh, I could not think of burying another husband." She died 12 years after him. Account books of the store and farm at Woodstock, Connecticut begun by her first husband were kept by Marion until 1811.
m. 28 SEP 1769 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, Charles Church Chandler, b. 11 JAN 1746 Woodstock, Windham Co., Connecticut, d. 9 AUG 1787 Woodstock, Windham Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesCHARLES graduated from Harvard College in 1763. He was a lawyer and member of the Committee of Correspondence and the Continental Congress. He had a store and farm at Woodstock, Massachusetts.
9 children: Dorothy Church, Samuel, Marion, Ursula, Charles, Hannah, Sally, Esther, Elizabeth.

NotesMARIAN was considered a very beautiful, brilliant and outspoken woman. When Justin Ely, who became her 3rd husband, proposed marriage she replied, "Oh, I could not think of burying another husband." She died 12 years after him. Account books of the store and farm at Woodstock, Connecticut begun by her first husband were kept by Marion until 1811.

(9) Sarah Spencer Lane9 (William Griswold Lane8, Ebenezer Lane7, Marian Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 MAR 1853 Sandusky, Erie Co., Ohio, d. 19 JAN 1935 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
(9) Wolcott Griswold Lane9 (William Griswold Lane8, Ebenezer Lane7, Marian Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 JAN 1866 Sandusky, Erie Co., Ohio, d. 11 NOV 1956 .
NotesWOLCOTT graduated from Yale University with a degree in law in 1888. He was a lawyer and argued before the New York Surogate Court. He was one of the Executors of the will of William Augustus Spencer who died in the sinking of the Titanic in 1912, as well as executor for Williams brother, Lorrilard Spencer. His transcripts of the papers of Roger Griswold are in the Connecticut Historical Society.

(10) Marian Hubbard10 (Gertrude McCurdy9, Richard Henry McCurdy8, Ursula Wolcott Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1864 , d. ABT 1864 .
(7) Elizabeth Griswold7 (John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 OCT 1778 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 22 JUN 1857 .
m. 28 MAR 1802 New London, New London Co., Connecticut, Jacob Baker Gurley, b. 2 AUG 1771 Mansfield, Tolland Co., Connecticut, d. 24 SEP 1856 New London, New London Co., Connecticut.
Spouse Notes Jacob B. Gurley, Esq., pf New London, Conn., w'as born in the town of Mansfield, Tolland Co., Conn., Aug. 2, 1771 (house shows by photo.). He attended the common schools of the town, and graduated at Dartmouth College in 1793. He was principal or preceptor of the Union School at New London, studied law, and was admitted to the bar in 1797, and became one of the ablest lawyers in New London County. Mr. Gurley was one of the incorporators of the Savings Bank at New London, 1827. He was a public spirited man, and did much for the advancement of the town and city. Soon after the death of his father, he became the owner of the homestead, which he owned the remainder of his life, and rented it during these years to his son-in-law, Mr. An- son Turner. After the death of Mr. Gurley this farm came into the pos- session of his son-in-law, Mr. Charles A. Gurley, who kept it but a few years, and then sold it. This farm had been in the possession of the Gurleys for over a century, and is situated a little south of the old Gurley burying-ground. Charles Griswold Gurley, son of Jacob B. Gurley, Esq., graduated at Yale College, 1827, and died July 4, 1828.
11 children: Charles, Sarah, Mary Brainard, Charles, Elizabeth, Ursula Wolcott, Hannah Brigham, John Griswold, Ellen, Lydia Ann, Ann.
(8) Charles Gurley8 (Elizabeth Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 19 APR 1803 , d. 1 OCT 1805 .
(8) Sarah Gurley8 (Elizabeth Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 26 NOV 1804 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 21 MAR 1835 .

m. John Lyon Gardiner, b. 1770 , d. 1816 .
Spouse NotesJOHN was 7th lord of the manor of Gardiner's Island, the only entailed estate in America. His father died when he was 4 years old and his uncle, Abraham Gardiner was his guardian until he came of age in 1791.

NotesWOLCOTT graduated from Yale University with a degree in law in 1888. He was a lawyer and argued before the New York Surogate Court. He was one of the Executors of the will of William Augustus Spencer who died in the sinking of the Titanic in 1912, as well as executor for Williams brother, Lorrilard Spencer. His transcripts of the papers of Roger Griswold are in the Connecticut Historical Society.
(9) Charles Chandler Griswold Lane9 (Elizabeth Diodate Griswold8, Charles Chandler Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 16 DEC 1867 Sandusky, Erie Co., Ohio, d. 7 MAY 1896 ,, New York.
(8) Sarah Johnson Griswold8 (Charles Chandler Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 MAY 1827 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. 30 JUN 1847 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, Lorillard Spencer, b. 1826 New York City, New York, d. 1888 Paris, Seine, France.
7 children: Elvira, William Augustus, George Griswold, Charles, Eleanora, Lydia, Lorillard.
(9) Elvira Spencer9 (Sarah Johnson Griswold8, Charles Chandler Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1850 ,, New York, d. .
(9) William Augustus Spencer9 (Sarah Johnson Griswold8, Charles Chandler Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 JAN 1855 New York City, New York, d. 15 APR 1912 North Bolton Cemetery, North Bolton, Tolland Co., Connecticut.
NotesWILLIAM was raised and educated in Europe. He became a New York socialite and bibliophile. He and his wife Marie boarded the "Titanic" as 1st Class Passenger at Cherbough on Wednesday April 10th, 1912. They had ticket No. 17569, cost 146 10s 10d, and Cabin No. B78. Marie survied the sinking in boat 6 and was picked up by the "Carpathia" and disembarked at New York City on Thursday, April 18th, 1912.

"William Augustus Spencer, who was drowned when the Titanic sank on April 15,1912, left a net estate of $2,218,650, according to an appraisal filed yesterday. The beneficiaries are Mrs. Marie Eugenie Spencer, his widow, $1,273,071; Lorillard Spencer, his nephew, $396,683; the New York Public Library, $394,095; and Eleanora L. S. Cenci, Princess de Vicovaro, his sister, $50,000. Mr. Spencer's estate was made up of these assets: Real estate, $893,622; bank accounts, $122,200; household goods, furniture, books, and pictures at his Throgs Neck Farm in the Bronx, $1,088; a half share in a ruby ring, $2,500; bonds and mortgages, $332,085; stocks and bonds, $932,016, and commissions due as the executor of other estates, $48,573. A claim for $2,670 against the owners of the Titanic for personal property which went down with the steamer was appraised at not more than $500. Included in Mr. Spencer's bequest to the New York Public Library was a library composed chiefly of French books. These were appraised at $40,779. Some of the volumes were: "Une Femme de Qualit au Sicle Pass," by Maurice Leloir, $4,000; "Ftes Galantes," by Paul Verlaine, $2,000; "La Dame de Monsereau," by Alexandre Dumas, $1,500; "La Vengeance des Peaux de Bique," by Gustave Toudouze, $1,400: "The Lady of Shalott," by Alfred Tennyson, $1,000; "La Reliure du XIXe Sicle," by Henri Beraldi, $1,000; "La Tribu Indienne," by Lucien Bonaparte, $1,000; "Pastels Tirages Successifs," by P. Bourget, $1,000; "Histoire d'un Epingle," by Segur, $800; "Jacques le Fataliste et son Maitre," by D. Diderot, $750; "La Mouche," by Alfred de Musset, $720; "Daphnis and Chloe," by Longus, $720; "Les Contes Drolatiques," by Honor de Balzac, $700; "Notre Dame de Paris," by Victor Hugo, $650; "The Three Musketeers," by Alexandre Dumas, $600; and "Zadig ou le Destine," by Voltaire, $600. Mr. Spencer owned this real estate: 183 Water Street, $20,000; 37 Allen Street, $20,500; 395 Grand Street, $30,000; 181-185 Forsyth Street, $66,000; 100 West Seventy-seventh Street, $70,000; 2,046-2,050 Seventh Avenue, $72,000; Throgs Neck Farm, the Bronx, $445,500; Williamsbridge Farm, the Bronx, $240,000; interest in property on Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, $12,400. Mortgages and taxes reduced the net value of the realty to $893,622." New York Times, 10 July 1914.
m. Marie Eugenie , b. 1867 Paris, Seine, France, d. 26 OCT 1913 Paris, Seine, France.
(9) George Griswold Spencer9 (Sarah Johnson Griswold8, Charles Chandler Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. ABT 1856 New York City, New York, d. .

(9) Lorillard Spencer9 (Sarah Johnson Griswold8, Charles Chandler Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 14 FEB 1860 New York City, New York, d. 14 MAR 1912 New York City, New York.

(10) Lorillard Spencer10 (Lorillard Spencer9, Sarah Johnson Griswold8, Charles Chandler Griswold7, John Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 4 JUL 1883 New York City, New York, d. 9 JUN 1939 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island.
NotesLORILLARD received $396,683 in 1914 from the estate of his uncle, William Augustus Spencer who when down with the "Titanic" on 15 April 1912.
(6) Ursula Griswold6 (Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 APR 1754 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 27 NOV 1781 .
m. 22 NOV 1777 Lynde McCurdy, b. 4 APR 1755 , d. NOV 1804 .
2 children: Ursula, John.
(7) Ursula McCurdy7 (Ursula Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 AUG 1778 , d. ABT 1819 .
m. John Allen, b. 12 JUN 1763 , d. 31 JUL 1812 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesJohn studied law at the Litchfield Law School and was admitted to the bar in 1786. He was a member of the Connecticut House of Representatives 1793-6, and a Representative to Congress 1797-9, a member of the state Council and Supreme Court of Errors 1800-6, after which he practiced law at Litchfield. He was called "Long John Allen", and a poet.
1 children: John,
(8) John Allen8 (Ursula McCurdy7, Ursula Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1802 , d. 1887 Washington, District of Columbia.
NotesJOHN moved from Litchfield to study law at Cleveland, Ohio, under Judge Samuel Cowles, about 1825. He was admitted to the Cleveland bar, and was the last president of the village council. When Cleveland became a city he was mayor and postmaster, state Senator, Representative to Congress, banker, and railroad director.
m. Warren, Trumbull Co., Ohio, Anna Maria Perkins, b. , d. .
Spouse NotesANNA died three months after her marriage.
(8) John Allen8 (Ursula McCurdy7, Ursula Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1802 , d. 1887 Washington, District of Columbia.
NotesJOHN moved from Litchfield to study law at Cleveland, Ohio, under Judge Samuel Cowles, about 1825. He was admitted to the Cleveland bar, and was the last president of the village council. When Cleveland became a city he was mayor and postmaster, state Senator, Representative to Congress, banker, and railroad director.

(6) Matthew Griswold6 (Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 APR 1760 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 10 JUN 1842 .
NotesMATTHEW was Judge of the Supreme Court of Connecticut.
m. 4 SEP 1788 Lydia Ely, b. 12 SEP 1766 , d. .
(6) Roger Griswold6 (Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 29 MAR 1762 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 25 OCT 1812 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesROGER graduated from Yale College in 1780 and was admitted to the bar in 1783. In 1794 he was elected to Congress to represent Lyme. He served there for ten years. His fight with Representative Matthew Lyon, which led to a physical fight on the floor of the House of Representatives, created quite a stir. He was offered the post of Secretary of War by John Adams, but declined. In 1807 he was appointed a Judge of the Superior Court, and in 1809 was chosen Lieutenant Governor. He was elected Governor of Connecticut in 1811.
m. 27 OCT 1788 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, Fanny Rogers, b. 23 MAR 1767 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 27 DEC 1863 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
11 children: Ellen E., Augustus Henry, Charles Chandler, Matthew, Roger Wolcott, Eliza Woodbridge, Mary Ann "Marian", William Frederick, Robert Harper, James, Frances Ann.
(7) Ellen E. Griswold7 (Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .

NotesAUGUSTUS was a ship's captain.

(9) Grace Card Selden9 (Lydia Marie Griswold8, Matthew Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 OCT 1865 Erie, Erie Co., Pennsylvania, d. .
m. Frederick Lincoln Chapin, b. 1863 Erie, Erie Co., Pennsylvania, d. 9 DEC 1913 .
(8) Matthew Griswold8 (Matthew Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 JUN 1833 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 19 MAY 1919 Erie, Erie Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesMATTHEW moved to Erie, Pennsylvania, in 1865 and formed a partnership with his cousins, John and Samuel Selden, "The Selden and Griswold Manufacturing Co. ", manufacturing iron goods. He bought out the Seldens in 1884. He was a member of the 53rd and 54th Congresses.

(10) Ursula Wolcott Griswold10 (William Edward Schenck Griswold9, Matthew Griswold8, Matthew Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 JUN 1908 Greenwich, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. 11 MAY 1998 Berkeley, Alameda Co., California.
(10) Adela Sloane Griswold10 (William Edward Schenck Griswold9, Matthew Griswold8, Matthew Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .
(10) Evelyn Griswold10 (William Edward Schenck Griswold9, Matthew Griswold8, Matthew Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 JUN 1911 Lenox, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 3 MAR 1946 .
(10) William Edward Schenck Griswold10 (William Edward Schenck Griswold9, Matthew Griswold8, Matthew Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 JUL 1912 , d. .
(10) John Sloane Griswold10 (William Edward Schenck Griswold9, Matthew Griswold8, Matthew Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 26 JUL 1914 Lenox, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts, d. .
NotesJOHN graduated from Yale University in 1937.
He is a etired member of Griswold, Heckel & Kelly Associates, a design and space-planning company and Plaut-Griswold Associates, an international exhibit design group.
He is chairman of the International College at Beirut, Lebanon, chairman and president of the Children's Aid Society of New York, national vice-president of the Boys Club of America, trustee of the Pomfret School and former trustee of Greenwich Country Day School.
During World War II he was W & J Sloane's director of shipbuilding contracts with Newport News Co.
He has served for half a century as a member of the Class Executive Committee and has endowed a scholarship at the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies.

Spouse NotesCAROLINE ran the Perkins School at New London. She taught her niece, Florence Griswold, to play the piano.

(9) Harold Ely Griswold9 (William Noyes Griswold8, William Frederick Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 16 OCT 1870 Of New York City,, New York, d. 1952 .

(10) Alfred Whitney Griswold10 (Harold Ely Griswold9, William Noyes Griswold8, William Frederick Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 OCT 1906 Morristown, Morris Co., New Jersey, d. 19 APR 1963 New Haven, New Haven Co., Connecticut.
NotesALFRED received his B.A. from Yale in 1929 and Ph.D. in 1933. He was instructor in History in 1933, Research Assistant in International Relations in 1935; Assistant Professor of Government and International Relations in 1938; Associate Professor in 1942; and Director, United States Army Specialized Training Program, Foreign area and Language Studies; and Director, United States Army Civil Affairs Training School. He was an Alumni Trustee, The Hotchkiss School in 1943 and Professor of History at Yale in 1947. In 1948 he published "Farming and Democracy" and in 1950 was elected President of Yale University. He received Honorary Degrees from Harvard University, Princeton University, Trinity College, Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Brown University, Columbia University, the University of Pennsylvania, Wesleyan University, Johns Hopkins University, Williams College and the University of Bridgeport.

(7) Robert Harper Griswold7 (Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1806 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 1882 .
NotesROBERT was a ship Captain.
m. Helen Maria Powers, b. 1820 , d. 1899 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesHELEN opened her home as a girls' finishing school, the Griswold Home School, in 1878, giving instruction in French, painting, drawing, and music.
4 children: Louise Augusta, Helen Adele "Adele", Robert Harper, Florence.
(8) Louise Augusta Griswold8 (Robert Harper Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 8 OCT 1841 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 12 APR 1896 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesLOUISE was the organist for the First Congregational Church at Old Lyme for 40 years.
(8) Helen Adele "Adele" Griswold8 (Robert Harper Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 29 MAR 1844 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 27 FEB 1913 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesHELEN and her sister, Florence, lived in the family home after their mother's death, taking in borders and selling plants and vegetables from their garden to make ends meet. In 1899 the artist, Henry Ward Ranger, came to board with them, and he encouraged other artists to stay there and to form an artist's colony at Old Lyme. Shortly after the colony was formed, Adele got tuberculosis and went to live in a sanitarium at Hartford, after which Florence ran the boarding house.
(8) Robert Harper Griswold8 (Robert Harper Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1847 , d. 21 SEP 1864 .
NotesROBERT died of dyptheheria at age 16.
(Medical):ROBERT died of Dyptheria at age 16.
(8) Florence Griswold8 (Robert Harper Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 25 DEC 1850 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 6 DEC 1937 Old Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
NotesFLORENCE ran the family home as a boarding house for artists and an art gallery after her sister moved to a sanitarium. In 1921 the Lyme Art Association opened a gallery next to her home on land she gave them for this purpose. She was considered a patron of the American Impressionist movement. She became the first manager of the gallery, receiving a percentage of the sales. In 1936 a conservator was appointed for her and her property sold, but she retained life tenancy. The home is now th "Florence Griswold Museum.

(9) Sarah Spencer Lane9 (William Griswold Lane8, Frances Ann Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 5 MAR 1853 Sandusky, Erie Co., Ohio, d. 19 JAN 1935 Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut.
(9) Wolcott Griswold Lane9 (William Griswold Lane8, Frances Ann Griswold7, Roger Griswold6, Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 JAN 1866 Sandusky, Erie Co., Ohio, d. 11 NOV 1956 .
NotesWOLCOTT graduated from Yale University with a degree in law in 1888. He was a lawyer and argued before the New York Surogate Court. He was one of the Executors of the will of William Augustus Spencer who died in the sinking of the Titanic in 1912, as well as executor for Williams brother, Lorrilard Spencer. His transcripts of the papers of Roger Griswold are in the Connecticut Historical Society.

(6) Sally Griswold6 (Ursula Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. Chandler, b. , d. .
(5) Oliver Wolcott5 (Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 20 NOV 1726 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 DEC 1797 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesOLIVER WOLCOTT, born 20 Nov. 1726 Windsor, Connecticut; died 1 Dec. 1797 Litchfield, Connecticut, buried East Cemetery, Litchfield. Oliver graduated first in his class from Yale in 1747. In the same year he was commissioned a Captain by Gov. Clinton of New York and raised a company of men which he lead in defense of the northern frontiers against the French and the Indians. After the peace of Aix-la-Chapelle his unit was disbanded and he returned to Connecticut and studied medicine under his brother, Alexander. Oliver moved from Goshen, Connecticut, to Litchfield about 1750. In that year his father was elected Governor of Connecticut. From 1751 to 1771 he was Sheriff of Litchfield County. In 1753 he built a large house at Litchfield, on land given him by his father. This home is the oldest house at Litchfield, and was lately occupied by his descendant, Mrs. Alice Wolcott Sherman. Washington and Lafayette visited the home, and Washington stayed here on his visit to Litchfield in 1780. He married Laura Collins 21 January 1755, by whom he had five children, one dying in infancy. One son, Oliver Wolcott. Jr., was a Governor of Connecticut. Oliver was elected a Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1764 and served until 1770. He was an Assistant to the Governor from 1771 to 1786. He was also a Judge of Probate from 1772 to 1795, and chief Judge of the Court of Common Pleas from 1774 to 1786. He rose through the ranks of the Connecticut militia, from Captain to Major-General. In 1775, he was appointed one of the Commissioners of Indian Affairs, charged with inducing the Indians to remain neutral during the struggle with Great Britain. He was appointed as a representative of Connecticut to the Continental Congress in 1776, taking his seat there in January, 1776. Becoming ill in June, during the discussion of the Declaration of Independence, he returned to Connecticut. He led fourteen units of the Connecticut militia to the defense of New York. On 9 July, 1776, a group of patriots tore down the lead statue of George III on Bowling Green in New York City. Oliver had it taken by cart to his home at Litchfield. His family and neighbors melted the lead in the Wolcott's apple orchard, molding 42,000 bullets for Washington's army. He returned to Philadelphia where he signed his name to the Declaration of Independence on 4 September 1776. Oliver spent the summer of 1777 recruiting troops from Connecticut, and with the rank of Major General, he commanded the Connecticut militia at the Battle of Saratoga, where British General Burgoyne was defeated. He rejoined the Continental Congress at York, Pennsylvania, and went with it when it moved to Baltimore in the winter of 1777-8. He signed the Articles of Confederation as representative for Connecticut on 15 Nov, 1777. In 1779 he commanded a division of militia defending the Connecticut coast. In 1780, he was one of the three commissioners appointed to arrange for supplies for the French troops at Newport, Rhode Island. He served with the militia until 1780, and, except for 1799, he represented Connecticut in the Continental Congress until 1784. In 1784 and 1785 he was one of the Commissioners for Indian Affairs charged with establishing terms of peace with the Iroquois. He helped negotiate the "Purchase of 1784", which legally cleared all Indians from the land northwest of the Allegheny River. Oliver, and his sons, Oliver and Frederick, were given land grants at Elmore, New Hampshire, for his service in the wars. He was also given land near Wolcott, New Hampshire, named for him because of his support for making New Hampshire a state. He was a member of the Susquehanna Company, a group of Connecticut investors who sold land in the Wyoming Valley to settlers. This land was claimed by both Connecticut and Pennsylvania. At a meeting of the Susquehanna Company in 1785, he is said to have presented a draft of a constitution for a new state in that area, to be called "Westmoreland". He was involved in negotiations for resolving the "Wyoming Controversy". The resuts of this negotiation was that the Wyoming Valley belonged to Pennsylvania. He was also involved in negotiating a land dispute between Vermont and New York. Oliver was a slave owner. In 1786 he freed a slave named Caesar, giving him the surname, Jamus. In 1790, his family at Litchfield consisted of 3 males over 16, 1 female, and 6 slaves. From 1786 to 1796 Oliver was Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut. He was an ardent Federalist. He was granted an honorary LLD degree by Yale University. In 1796 he was a Presidential Elector and voted for John Adams. Upon the death of Governor Huntington, he became Governor of Connecticut, holding office until he died the following year. The town of Farmingbury, Connecticut, changed it's name to Wolcott when Oliver cast the tie-breaking vote in 1796, to allow it to seperate from the town of Waterbury, of which it had been a part. Oliver was described as tall, erect, and dignified, with a dark complexion. Two portraits of him, painted by Ralph Earle, have survived. One was presented to the State Senate of Connecticut by his grandson, Dr. John Stoughton Wolcott. It is now in the Connecticut State Library. The other is owned by the Connecticut Historical Society. Oliver's letters and papers are deposited with the Connecticut Historical Society. His statue was one of those placed on the Connecticut State House, added in 1916 by a vote of various Connecticut patriotic societies.
m. 21 JAN 1755 Laura Collins, b. 1 JAN 1732 Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 19 APR 1794 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesLAURA's portrait, painted by Ralph Earl, is in the Virginia Art Museum in Richmond, Virginia.
5 children: Oliver, Oliver, Laura, Mariann, Frederick,
(6) Oliver Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 31 AUG 1757 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 13 SEP 1757 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(6) Oliver Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 11 JAN 1760 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 1 JUN 1833 New York City, New York.
NotesOLIVER attended Nathaniel Beckwith's grammar school, and in 1773 enrolled at Yale College. He served with the Litchfield militia in 1777 when they fought to keep the British from capturing the colonist's supplies at Danbury. He graduated from Yale in 1778, at the age of 18, and served as an military aide to his father in 1779. He studied law at Litchfield, and was admitted to the bar in 1781. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. Oliver began practicing law in Hartford, and became a clerk in the state Treasury office, and was a member of the pay-table committee from 1782 to 1788, Connecticut State Comptroller of Public Accounts 1788-9, Auditor 1789-91, Comptroller of the U.S. Treasury 1791-5, and U.S. Secretary of the Treasury 1795-1800, succeeding Alexander Hamilton in the Cabinets of Presidents Washington and Adams. He resigned due to slander from his Republican opponents, being accused of starting a fire in the Treasury office to conceal peculations. Oliver was appointed by President Adams as a Judge of the Circuit Court in 1801, and served until 1802. He then established a mercantile business in New York City, where he was President of the Merchants' Bank of the City of New York from 1803 to 1804. He was living in Ward 2, New York City, in 1810, with a family of 1 male born before 1765 (Oliver), 1 male born 1765-85 (servant ?), 2 males born 1800-10 (Oliver, John), 2 females born 1775-85 (servants ?), and 2 females born 1785-95 (Laura, Elizabeth). These may have included his Negro servants, Julia b. 1780, Peggy Zillah born 1786, Chloe born 1788, and Chloe born 1791. He was one of the founders, and President of the Bank of North America from 1812 to 1814. Oliver and his brother, Frederick, established a large woolen mill on the Naugatuck River in Torrington Township in 1813, and the village of Orleans there was changed to Wolcottville in their honor. This became the city of Torrington in 1881. In 1815 Oliver was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor of Connecticut on the Democratic ticket. He was elected Governor of Connecticut in 1817, and was President of the Connecticut Constitutional Convention in 1818. He served as Governor until 1827. He was an ardent Federalist, an intimated friend and advisor of Washington, Adams and Hamilton, and for some time was the last surviving member of Washington's Cabinet. Oliver was associated with Julius Demming and Benjamin Tallmadge in the Litchfield China Trading Company. One of their ships, "The Trident", sailed between America and China for 14 years. Oliver was Grand Master of the Masonic Lodge of Connecticut from 1818 to 1820. He was awarded honorary LLD degrees from Yale, Princeton, and Brown Universities. Oliver purchased a large home at Litchfield near his father's house where his brother, Frederick, lived. He planted 13 sycamore trees along South St. at Litchfield, commemorating the 13 colonies. All but one of these were killed by disease, so Oliver and his brother planted elm trees to replace them. After retiring from public service, Oliver lived with his son, John, in New York City. His will left "to my beloved and only surviving son, Doctor John Stoughton Wolcott, who resides with me and is the protector of my declining years," all his books and papers and household effects and his home and property at Litchfield; $100 to his son-in-law William Gracie; and the remainder to be divided between his children, John and Laura. He requested that John provide for the support and education of his grandson, Oliver WolcottIV. In 1844 his sole surviving heirs were Mrs. Laura Gibbs of New York City, and a grandson, Oliver Wolcott of Litchfield, Connecticut.

"28 Jan. 1796, Philadelphia: letter from Wm. V. Murray to George McHenry on his nomination as Secretary of War: ... as to the Salary, it will maintain you in that easy style of elegant but quiet accomodation which I think you love at all events it does Wolcott & Pickering. The first lives in Fourth South, at the corner of Spruce, in a
neat house of two rooms, one small, on a floor and must I think live within his means. He is a very worthy man & quite equal to his duty; his wife one of the mildest & most amiable women in town an excellent manager, kind but economical.

Oliver's portrait was presented to the Connecticut State Senate by his son, Dr. John Stoughton Wolcott. A facimile of it was put on the 2 cent Revenue Stamp in 1945. His letters and papers were deposited with the Conneticut Historical Society.

A painting of Oliver dated 1806 said to have been painted in 1806 for the Hon. Josiah Quincy and bequeathed by him to Oliver Wolcott Gibbs (1822-1908); or alternatively, it was given by the subject to his daughter, Mrs. George Gibbs III (Laura Wolcott), who gave it to her son, Oliver Wolcott Gibbs. Oliver Wolcott Gibbs' niece, Laura Henriette d'Oremieulx, later Mrs. J. West Roosevelt, New York, great-granddaughter of the subject; her gift in 1933 to her son, Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, New York (died July 15, 1953); owned by 1966, Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, Jr., Birmingham, Alabama (on permanent loan to Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham, in 1997, still owned by O.W. Roosevelt, Jr.. A copy of this portrait is owned by George Gibbs, New York. See also the copy by G.L. Nelson owned by New-York Historical Society, New York. This copy by Nelson is owned by First National City Bank of New York (Citibank). A copy is at the United States Treasury Department.
m. 1 JUN 1785 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Elizabeth Stoughton, b. 27 OCT 1767 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 SEP 1805 New York City, New York.
7 children: John Stoughton, Oliver, Laura, Elizabeth Stoughton, Oliver Stoughton, John Stoughton, Henry.
(7) John Stoughton Wolcott7 (Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 28 AUG 1787 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 4 FEB 1789 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
(7) Oliver Wolcott7 (Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 MAY 1790 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 17 JUL 1791 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
(7) Laura Wolcott7 (Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 10 APR 1794 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 10 DEC 1870 New York City, New York.
NotesLAURA was strong and fortright, according to her grandson. She was an ardent abolitionist, and helped hide runaway slaves in New York City. Later in life she became an amateur artist.
m. 27 DEC 1810 New York City, New York, George Gibbs, b. 7 JAN 1776 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, d. 6 AUG 1833 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
Spouse NotesGEORGE was a gentleman farmer on Long Island. He had a large house called "Sunswick", near Astoria, New York, overlooking the East River. He was an amateur scientist and mineralologist. The mineral, Gibbsite, was named for him. He was named vice-president of the New York Lyceum of Natural History in 1822. His huge collection of rocks and minerals, formed by the purchase of European collections and his own purchases, was the largest in the United States. The collection was purchased by Yale University in 1825. His large collection of books, purchased when he was in Europe, is now in the Yale University library. The Smithsonian Institution's Museum of American History has a five piece silver tea set with the Gibbs coat-of-arms, showing three battle-axes, made by Chaudron of Philadelphia, probably before 1819. This was owned by George and Laura, and may have been a wedding present. His father-in-law, Oliver Wolcott, lived with him at the time of Oliver's death.
7 children: George, Mary, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza", Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott", Alfred, Laura Wolcott, Francis Sarason.
(8) George Gibbs8 (Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 JUL 1815 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 19 APR 1873 New Haven, Oswego Co., New York.
NotesGEORGE attended the Round Hill School of Northampton, and graduated from Harvard College in 1838. In his early 20s he travelled extensively in Europe, making scetches of towns in Germany and Switzerland. This sketch book was in the possession of his descendant, Robert Nowell Williams Jr.. He was a lawyer, antiquarian, and Librarian of the New York Historical Society. In 1846 he published "Memoirs of the Administration of Washington and John Adams, Edited from the Papers of Oliver Wolcott, Secretary of the Treasury". George marched overland from St. Louis to Oregon in 1854. He was appointed Collector of the Port of Astoria, Oregon, in 1854, and served on the Boundary Commission. He was appointed to the boundary survey team in 1857. In 1860 he returned East and was employed by the Smithsonian Institution editing documents about Indian culture. He was the author of several works on Indian languages published by the Smithsonian. He moved to New Haven, Connecticut in 1871. He gave the chest owned by Henry Wolcott, the immigrant, to the Connecticut Historical Society. He married his first cousin.
m. 11 APR 1871 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, Mary Kane Gibbs, b. 19 JAN 1827 , d. 18 DEC 1876 .
(8) Mary Gibbs8 (Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1818 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 2 JUN 1820 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
(8) Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8 (Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 8 JUL 1819 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 25 AUG 1906 Stockbridge, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
m. 2 APR 1844 New York City, New York, Lucius Tuckerman, b. 19 MAR 1818 Chelsea, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 10 JUN 1890 Stockbridge, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesLUCIUS was a merchant in New York City, living at Manhattan in 1880. In 1879 he built a six story apartment house on Washington Square exclusively for bachelors, which became the home of notable artists such as Winslow Homer, Albert Ryder, Rockwell Kent, Edward Hopper, etc. He was an early benefactor of the Metropolitam Museum of Art and on the Social Register.
9 children: Lucius Carey, Alfred, Walter Cary, Laura Wolcott, Rupert, Emily, Bayard, Paul, Lucy.
(9) Lucius Carey Tuckerman9 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 AUG 1846 , d. 23 SEP 1849 .
(9) Alfred Tuckerman9 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 15 JAN 1848 , d. 24 MAY 1925 .

(10) Wolcott Tuckerman10 (Walter Cary Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 APR 1880 , d. 15 FEB 1973 King, San Bernardino Co., California.
NotesWOLCOTT lived at Ipswich, Massachusetts from 1903 to 1913, and then moved to a ranch at Carpinteria, California.
(10) Walter Rupert Tuckerman10 (Walter Cary Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 23 DEC 1882 , d. 15 JAN 1961 .
(9) Laura Wolcott Tuckerman9 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 AUG 1850 ,, New York, d. 9 FEB 1914 .
m. 9 APR 1891 Washington, District of Columbia, James Lowndes, b. , d. .
(9) Rupert Tuckerman9 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 16 DEC 1851 , d. 23 NOV 1871 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island.
(9) Emily Tuckerman9 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 6 NOV 1853 ,, New York, d. .
(9) Bayard Tuckerman9 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 JUL 1855 New York City, New York, d. ABT 1920 .
NotesBAYARD graduated from Harvard in 1878; studied in Europe, and wrote on literary and historical subjects for periodicals. In 1880 he is described as an iron merchant, living with his parents at New York City. In 1898 he became lecturer on English Literature at Princeton University, a position he still held in 1903. He was the author of: "History of England Prose Fiction" (1882); "Life of General Lafayette with a Critical Estimate of his Character and Public Acts" (1889); and edited with an introduction, "Diary of Philip Hone" (1889); "Peter Stuyvesant" (1893); "William Jay and the Abolition of Slavery" (1893) and "Life of General Philip Schuyler" (1903). He was on the New York City Social Register.
m. 26 SEP 1882 Ipswich, Essex Co., Massachusetts, Anna Osgood Smith, b. 20 FEB 1862 New York City, New York, d. .
4 children: Elisabeth Wolcott, May Appleton, Bayard, Joan Cotton.
(10) Elisabeth Wolcott Tuckerman10 (Bayard Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 JUL 1882 Ipswich, Essex Co., Massachusetts, d. .
(10) May Appleton Tuckerman10 (Bayard Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 24 NOV 1886 ,, New York, d. .
(10) Bayard Tuckerman10 (Bayard Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 19 APR 1889 Morristown, Morris Co., New Jersey, d. MAR 1968 .
NotesBAYARD was a horse breeder and racetrack executive.
(10) Joan Cotton Tuckerman10 (Bayard Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 APR 1891 , d. .
(9) Paul Tuckerman9 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 17 NOV 1856 ,, New York, d. .
NotesPAUL is described as an iron merchantat New York City in 1880. He built a large home at Tuxedo Park, New York, and was one of the original trustees of the Tuxedo Park Library.
m. 3 MAR 1886 Susan Minturn , b. 3 MAR 1865 , d. .
1 children: Dorothy.
(10) Dorothy Tuckerman10 (Paul Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 NOV 1889 Tuxedo Park, Orange Co., New York, d. 10 MAR 1969 .
NotesDOROTHY was one of the leading interior decorators of her time. She founded the Architectural Clearing House in 1925. The business was later renamed Dorothy Draper & Co. he decorated hotels, apartment houses, restaurants and the private homes of the wealthy. She had three children.
(9) Lucy Tuckerman9 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 2 FEB 1858 Staten Island, Richmond Co., New York, d. 12 MAY 1904 .
m. 16 NOV 1882 Arthur George Sedgwick, b. 6 OCT 1844 New York City, New York, d. 14 JUL 1915 Pittsfield, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
2 children: Grace Ashburner, Susan Ridley.
(10) Grace Ashburner Sedgwick10 (Lucy Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 13 OCT 1883 , d. 23 JUN 1961 .
(10) Susan Ridley Sedgwick10 (Lucy Tuckerman9, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 10 SEP 1886 New York City, New York, d. .
(8) Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott" Gibbs8 (Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 21 FEB 1822 New York City, New York, d. 9 DEC 1908 .
NotesOLIVER dropped his first name at an early age, and called himself "Wolcott Gibbs". He entered Columbia College in 1837 and graduated in 1841. He then attended the College of Physicians and Surgeons there, qualifying as a medical doctor in 1845. He studied chemistry at the University of Berlin in the laboratories of Rose and Rammelsberg, and subsequently spent five months with Liebig in Giessen, returning to America in 1848. In that year he became professor of Chemistry at the Free Academy, which later became the University of the City of New York. In 1863 he became Rumsford Professor of Science at Harvard University which he held until his retirement in 1887. During the Civil War he was a member of the Executive Committee of the Sanitary Comission. In 1873 he was granted a LLD degree, and was appointed comissioner to the Vienna Exhibition. he was an honorary member of the German Chemical Society and the London Chemical Society, and one of the original members of the National Academy of Scienc. He is credited for introducing research into university requirements. In organic and analytical chemistry he discovered many new substances and developed new methods. His study of complex ammonia bases, double compounds, acids of metal, and metals of the platinum group, contributed markedly to the science of chemistry.
m. 1853 Josephine Mauran, b. , d. 16 FEB 1887 .
(8) Alfred Gibbs8 (Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 22 APR 1823 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 26 DEC 1868 Fort Leavenworth, Leavenworth Co., Kansas.
NotesALFRED graduated from the West Point Military Academy in 1846, and served in the Mexican War. As a Captain in the Civil War, he was taken prisoner by the Confederates and exchanged 27 August 1862. He was commissioned Colonel of the 130th New York Regiment of Volunteers on 6 September 1862. He reorganized his regiment as the 1st New York Dragoons in August 1863. He was appointed Brigadier General 19 Oct. 1864, and commanded a Brigade under Gen. Sheridan until 1865. He was present at the surrender of Gen. Lee. He mustered out of the army as a Major General 1 February 1866. He was then made a Major in the 7th U.S. Cavalry on 28 July 1866, serving under Gen. George Custer.
m. 27 DEC 1856 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, Peggy Forshee Blair, b. JAN 1825 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, d. 25 JUL 1908 .
2 children: Alfred Wolcott, John Blair "Blair".
(9) Alfred Wolcott Gibbs9 (Alfred Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 OCT 1856 Fort Filmore,, New Mexico, d. 19 MAY 1922 Wayne, Delaware Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesALFRED attended Rutgers College 1873-1874, and Stevens Institute of Technology 1874-1878, and entered railroad employment in 1879. He was a master mechanic and was Chief Mechanical Engineer on the Pennsylvania Railroad.
m. Marianne Everard Skelton, b. 1861 , d. .
1 children: Marianne Skelton.
(10) Marianne Skelton Gibbs10 (Alfred Wolcott Gibbs9, Alfred Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. , d. .

m. 1853 Theophile Marie Oremieulx, b. 11 MAY 1815 ,, France, d. 3 JUL 1881 .
Spouse NotesTHEOPHILE came to America to fight in the Revolutionary War. He was an officer in the American Army, and an Assistant Professor at West Point Military Academy.
2 children: Laura Henriette, Leon F..
(9) Laura Henriette Oremieulx9 (Laura Wolcott Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1858 , d. 23 MAR 1945 New York City, New York.
m. 26 FEB 1884 James West Roosevelt, b. 2 JUL 1858 , d. 10 APR 1896 .
Spouse NotesJAMES. MD Columbia University 1880, Clinical Lecturer on Medicine 1886. He was a first cousin of President Theodore Roosevelt.
5 children: Lewis West, Lorraine D'Oremieulx, Harold West, Oliver Wolcott, Nicholas.
(10) Lewis West Roosevelt10 (Laura Henriette Oremieulx9, Laura Wolcott Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 7 AUG 1885 , d. 12 JUN 1892 .
(10) Lorraine D'Oremieulx Roosevelt10 (Laura Henriette Oremieulx9, Laura Wolcott Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 1 JAN 1887 New York City, New York, d. 1965 .
(10) Harold West Roosevelt10 (Laura Henriette Oremieulx9, Laura Wolcott Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 9 JUN 1888 , d. 9 APR 1892 .
(10) Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt10 (Laura Henriette Oremieulx9, Laura Wolcott Gibbs8, Laura Wolcott7, Oliver Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Sarah Drake4, Job Drake3, Mary Wolcott2) b. 27 NOV 1890 New York City,, New York, d. 15 JUL 1953 New York City,, New York.
NotesOLIVER was a first cousin once removed of President Theodore Roosevelt. He graduated from Harvaard in 1912 and served in World Wat I. He was manager of a branch of the Farmers Loan & Trust Co. of New York, located in France, during World War I. He lived at Woodmere, Long Island, New York.

"The wedding of Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt of this city, a son of Mrs. J. West Roosevelt and the late Dr. J. West Roosevelt, who was a cousin of the late President Roosevelt, and Mrs. Verdery Akin McMichael, a daughter of Mrs. John W. Akin of Atlanta, Ga., and the late Judge Akin, was solemnized quietly at 12 o'clock yesterday noon..

1930 Hewlett NY
Oliver W Roosevelt 41, b. NY, stock broker
Verdery E Roosevelt 42, b. GA
